text: Sunlit illuminates the darkened stable, highlighting the  contours of a magnificent HORSE (PILGRIM) in surreal, dre like imagery: his legs, his muscles, his sheen, his mane. his eyes. He shakes his head and stamps his feet. He seem confined. Eager to run.
Pilgrim bursts through the stall and runs out the stables into a blinding white morning.

location: AN OPEN FIELD LEADING TO WOODS

text: Whiteness. Snow and sky without any discernible line betw Camera is POV, as if on the horse, riding through the  whiteness. Snow kicks up from the side. We hear the breat of the horse. As we travel on hills, through trees, we  experience of sense of wild, exhilarating freedom. We hear the giggles of a GIRL (GRACE) on the horse. An  occasional line;
Yeah, fly boy... that's it... go...  go... go... END OF DREAM as we CUT TO:

Grace awakens, calmly. Takes a breath. Slides out of bed stands before a window, overlooking a beautiful Connectic country house. We see a snow-covered field and distant wo Grace presses her faces against the cold, frosted window  eager to get out.
Alarm rings, ANNIE MACLEAN awakens. She shuts the alarm a scoots up in bed. She waits. Seconds later the television across the foot of her bed turns on from a timer -- to a 24 NEWS channel.
Grace, fully dressed except for her boots, tiptoes past a partially opened bedroom door. Her father ROBERT is aslee alone, on his huge king size bed.

Grace is putting on her boots on a bench beside a back do She is wearing her mother's outfit. As she slides the boo on, we see behind her a row of framed photos -- Robert, G and Annie in happy times. She slaps a note on the refrigerator, with a magnet -- "G riding. Back around 10. Love, G."
Grace slips on her jacket and hat as she comes down the  steps, her feet hitting the walk...
Annie's feet hit the ground, running -- her breath showin the cold air. She passes other joggers with ease. She cro the street and heads for an elegant CPW building.

Dressed in running clothes, Annie opens the door and pick several newspapers that were delivered. She carries them the kitchen and sets them beside a huge stack of publicat magazines, papers, etc... Knowing she must read all of th some point, she breathes a disgusted sign. She thumbs thr the POST as she pours herself a cup of coffee. Something  catches her eyes and she snarls:
That little shit! She dials a portable phone and moves through the apartmen she talks:

Hi Lucy?... Did I wake you?... Have  you read the Post?... They've got a  little item about me and Fiske. He's  saying I fired him and that I faked  the new circulation figures.. Ha, ha...  Oh, please... It's the last act of a  desperate gnome... Set up a phone call  with Don Farlow for 9:30... Throughout the phone call, Annie is selecting clothes,  turning on the shower, undressing...

The snow has stopped falling. Grace walks along a hill, h in pocket. Spread out on the landscape are horses, on a h farm, standing like statues in the white covered fields. As Grace comes along the hill, we see another GIRL (JUDIT coming from the opposite direction. She doesn't have Grac lean elegance but her warm, friendly smile brightens her  face. Upon reaching her, Grace returns the smile with a h
It's warmer than I thought.
You want to go to a movie tonight?
I thought your mom's coming up?
(prickly)
So? Judith immediately senses a problem so she continues casu as they begin walking away from Camera...
My parents are having friends from  college over. They're really nice...  They have this gorgeous son who wants  to be a forest ranger.
Can I come? I'll start a fire... Judith laughs as they continue talking, their voices trai off, as the girls head for the stables.

There are several horses in their stalls. Grace and Judit enter, talking, carrying their English saddles. Judith st at a stall, disappearing into it as she says "Hello?"..., Grace continues to the end stall. Pilgrim (the horse from the dream) stands looking at her.
Hello, beautiful boy. He's a massive figure beside her but she shows no inhibit She enters, touching his muzzle. He plays with her by nud her back.
Stop... Will you stop!
They lead their horses, now saddled and ready, from the b Pilgrim tosses his head, prancing, playing with the snow.
Show-off. The girls mount the horses and ride off together.

Annie, casually dressed, enters the empty offices of her  magazine. She turns on the light, revealing a large row o stalls and glassed in private offices. Everywhere we look see indications of the kind of magazine she edits. She strolls to her office -- the largest -- surrounded by windows. The office walls are covered with photos, most o which are COVER STORIES ON ANNIE. (One photo is of Annie's father MARTIN. A BRITISH AMBASSA with his young daughter on his lap, her arms affectionate around his neck. Her mother stands right behind them, pos like a member of the royal family.) Annie sits and takes a breath. The only photo on her desk a family portrait, taken when Annie was given the Crystal Award -- Robert, Grace, herself and the Award. She checks watch -- it is almost 9:30.

A WALK-IN CLOSET of the master bedroom; one side is Annie one side is Robert's. Robert stands before his bureau in the closet -- he has j showered and is putting on his watch and ring which lay  beside his cologne assortment. A FRAMED PHOTO OF HE AND A in India -- younger, vibrant, in love... when they first THE PHONE RINGS. Robert enters into the bedroom to pick u
Hello? INSERT ANNIE: They speak in dulled, emotionless voices:
It's me.
Hi.
Hi. Awkward pause.
So, what, uh, what train are you taking?
I should be in by two.
Okay. You want me to pick you up?
Sure... What's Grace up to?
Riding with Judith. Beat.
I'm sorry about last night. I shouldn't  have brought it up over the phone.
That's okay. We have to talk about it  and we're not always in the same place ... so... I just have to get used to it. (beat)
What do you want to do about dinner?
I don't know. We'll figure it out. Pause. There is a lot unspoken but understood between the Annie's other phone line rings. Robert hears it as well.
Okay. We'll see you later then.
Yeah. Bye. Annie picks up the other line and her manner brightens, h energy boosts...

DON! My love, how are you? Did you hear  about Fiske?... No, suing is too  civilized. Can't we get your friend at Le  Cirque to serve him a fatal piece of  poached salmon?... Ha, ha... That's even  better...

Long Shot of the girls riding at an easy pacing, talking the time. Grace is an elegant rider, quite self-assured f 13-year-old... We come into the scene at the moment the  girls have just shared a secret or a fantasy. Judith is  giggling uncontrollably. Grace laughs as she says:
...Oh, come on! You think the same thing!
I just could never say it! They stop at the end of the field, facing the woods.
Do you want to go around by the  old road?
Why don't we just cut through the  woods? Grace nods. They ride into the woods, continuing their ta

The girls ride down, along a stand of hickories and popla to a RIVER. They stop the horses and their conversation, listen to the sound of the water. Below them, off in the  distance, they can just make out a two-lane country road.
You want to go down or stay along  the river?
We already did the river. Let's go down  and across the old bridge. We can circle  back. They begin to make their way.

Annie's office is now crowded with a dozen or so employee sitting on the couch, on the window sills, on the arms of chairs, against the walls... Paper bag emptied of bagels, cream cheese, orange juice, paper plates... Hand Held Camera captures the energy of the room as it  follows overlapping lines, laughter, etc... yet, no matte casual it all seems, Annie is very much at the center of  control... We enter the scene of LAUGHTER, as Annie asks  KEVIN, a feature writer:
... So what did you say to her?
I said, thank you very much... (LAUGHTER, AD LIBS)
I really should do the interview... But  perhaps if you'd like to have dinner... LAUGHTER... Everyone starts Ad Libbing...
Dinner!!... He's so cute.... Why don't I  get those kind of interviews?... Look,  he has husband number eight written on  his forehead...
All right, all right, all right... Kevin,  good job. Write the interview. If I don't  like it, you may have to sleep with her  for a follow-up! (laughter)
Now... I'm thinking about another fashion  designer spread... Who's news out there? Characters shout out designer names and comments as the p rings and LUCY picks up... speaking amdist the talking...
Hold on. (presses hold)
Gottschalk. The room goes dead quiet, instantly. Then erupts in laugh as everyone realizes it. Annie, however, waves her hand a she takes the phone...
Quiet... Quiet! Everyone obeys. Annie presses SPEAKER PHONE.
David?
Who's there?
Everyone. Working overtime. Just for you.
Did you speak to Farlow?
Yes. We're suing.
Is that absolutely necessary? It'll just  make it a bigger story.

David, he signed an agreement that he  wouldn't talk to the press and he's  libeled me by saying I faked the figures.  You're not going soft on me, are you? Silence. Gottschalk doesn't immediately respond. Everyone waits. Covert looks between characters suggest this is  interesting -- has Annie over-stepped her bounds with the magazine's owner? Annie waits without a shred of anxiety even though she might have some. Finally:
Well, I suppose we could use another  good public feud...
Exactly... Everyone silently acknowledges Annie guts and influence.

It's perfectly still. We are looking down an empty TWO-LA ROAD covered with fresh snow. We see the girls slowly rid out of the woods, talking. They cross the road and start into the woods on the other side... They are trying to si LIZ PHAIR song, "CHOPSTICKS"
(singing)
"I met him at a party and he told me how  he like to drive me home... He said he  liked to do it backwards..."
(singing)
"... I said it--"
(singing)
"... and I said that"...
(stops singing)
No, wait, it just goes... "he said he  liked to do-"... Suddenly there's the SOUND OF THE METAL OF JUDITH'S HORSE scraping on some sheer ice hidden under the soft snow. Ju notices first...
What was -- The horse staggers... Judith looks to Grace --
Grace! The horse tries to find tracing with his hindfeet, kickin up sprays of snow and ice shards. The horse suddenly fall the ice and goes down hard on its knees...
The horse stumbles to get back on its feet, slipping agai Frightened, it rears and Judith, caught off balance, is  thrown, her foot catching in the stirrup...
Her horse, unable to find its balance, starts to slide ba down the incline.

Grace, directly behind Judith, tries to turn Pilgrim to a being hit by the errant horse. What follows, we see from Grace's perspective. The detail that form the images and sounds of Grace's mind are fast, disembodies, almost surreal as -- Judith's horse bulldozes into Pilgrim, taking his legs ou from under him, sending both horses careening down the ic slope. Grace hangs onto Pilgrim's neck. Judith, her leg  helplessly tangled in the stirrup, is dragged, her head  bouncing on the frozen ground. They slide all the way back down to the COUNTRY ROAD. Pil is the first to find his legs and stand. Grace manages to up in the saddle. She sees Judith's horse stumbling back its feet, one of his legs broken at the ankles, walking i confused circles, dragging Judith -- her face bleeding, h leg hanging from the stirrup.
(frightened)
Jude, you okay?
(softly, crying)

I'm okay... I'm okay. She tries to extricate her leg from the stirrup. Grace sees it before she hears it. A GLINT off of steel. then hear the rumbling SOUND of a TRUCK coming around the bend... The Girls on their horses in the middle of the ro The Truck, an 18 wheeler carrying logging equipment, come around the turn... Grace grabs the bridle, trying to get  Judith's horse out of the road... The driver, seeing them on the air horn. The Horses bolt at the sound, the bridle slipping out of Grace's hand...

... The horses turn apart. The Driver starts furiously  downshifting, trying to brake... He seems to get it under control when suddenly THE TRUCK SKIDS on some ice. It beg to slide, out of control, the truck bed and the cab jack- knifing. The truck literally plows over the helpless Judi and her horse -- the horse going down on the pavement, Ju disappearing under him. The truck's cab, like a mythic  monster, heads right for Grace and Pilgrim... Grace looks right into the Driver's helpless, frightened eyes... Sudd Pilgrim rears up at the truck, sending Grace flying, boun her off the pavement and under the wheel of the truck. Pilgrim instinctively jumps onto the hood of the truck, h hooves caught between the rear-view mirrors like some  grotesque ornament. His head and chest slams into the win shattering through the glass. And then it is still. The truck has stopped halfway in the road. Judith's horse lies in the road, motionless. Pilgrim, on the truck's hoo his legs splayed, stuck, his head and chest, bleeding. He shrieks, struggling to get to his feet. He manages to fre his legs and, stepping off the cab onto the road, walks o wounded, in pain, into the sanctuary of the woods... The Driver stumbles out of the cab, his head bleeding, in shock. He sits on the ground. All we hear is the sound of river and the wind in the trees. Grace, halfway under the truck, frozen, stares up at the  beautiful morning sky. WE HEAR THE SOUND OF A HELICOPTER...

ANGLE ON GRACE'S NOTE on the refrigerator as Robert enter from the outside with two bags of groceries. He places th the counter near the PHONE MACHINE. He sees ONE MESSAGE i there. He presses PLAY as he puts away the groceries. A BEAT LATER the PHONE RINGS and he picks up, with the ma still playing...
(on phone)
Hello? Paul, hi -- are you guys back?  How was it? Oh that sounds great. Oh  Paul.. hold on...
(on machine)

Robert! Are you there?... Robert! It's  Liz!... Look, there's... there's been  an accident... Uh... Jesus... uh... As Robert listens, the voice of Liz's on the machine from inside, pulls his attention. On hearing "accident," Rober lowers the receiver, frozen, as he listens to Liz...
(on machine)
Robert, just call me on my call phone...  1-917-449-7805...

Pilgrim is hiding in the shadows under an old railroad br standing up to his knees in the river. His chest is cut o bleeding. His face cut, contorted and swollen. LIZ HAMMON the local veterinarian, hides a hypodermic needle in her  jacket, quietly walking into the water. A Policeman is going into the water downstream from Pilgr whose chest is heaving, blood drips into the water. He  watches Liz. She is almost to him when suddenly he bolts, running upstream. The Policeman behind him shouts and waves his arm. Fright Pilgrim wheels back toward Liz, who manages to stick the in his neck. He rears, knocking her down, then runs out o the river, the hypo still in his neck. He runs for the  sanctuary of the woods.

Annie sits on a train -- her laptop out, notes beside her her cellular phone, ever-ready. The train passes through  beautiful countryside but Annie is focused on an editoria she's writing. The train pulls into a station and stops, causing Annie t take a break and stretch her arms and neck. She looks out window for the first time and sees: A MAN, his hands in his pockets, waiting on the platform. watches as the Man holds out his arms to his two young  children, who are getting off the train. He picks them up his wife enters the scene, kissing him and wrapping her a around his waist. The children talk a mile a minute and t father listens to every word. Annie doesn't even realize she is staring. As they leave platform, she turns back to her laptop. As the train begi to move again, Annie returns to work. HER CELLULAR PHONE RINGS. She answers.
Yeah?... Hi. I made the 1:00 so... The expression on her face sinks into a stunned panic.

Annie is running through the corridors, her bags in tow. sees Robert standing in the corridor talking to a DOCTOR. runs for them. When she appears, Robert and the Doctor stop their  conversation. Robert looks to Annie, who is waiting for n
Robert is teary eyed, beaten down.
Judith's dead. Annie's horrified, waiting for news of Grace.
What about Grace?
She was in pretty bad shape. They've  done a C.A.T. Scan -- she has some  hemorrhaging...
But nothing we can't handle...
(impatient)
Where is she now?
Surgery.
Surgery! For what-?
(interrupting)
Annie, her leg was shattered -- what  they call the distal epi.. epi..
Distal epicondyle of the femur...
(quietly, crying)
They have to take the leg off. Annie responds without tears and cries but with a quiet  shock. We can tell her mind is racing, trying to process information, until finally she asks:
Which leg? The Doctor and Robert are surprised by the question.
What difference does it make? Annie stares for a beat, then nods apologetically.
Pilgrim is sedated, lying in his own blood in the snow,  surrounded by Police and trackers. He is being attended t LIZ HAMMOND, who is dictating to her assistant:
... His skull, cheek, and nose are  severely fractured. He has a deep  chest wound. I'm not even sure it  can be closed.
(deadpan, local accent)
Animal should be put down -- anybody can  see that. Liz looks up to him, resentfully, but knows he's right.

Camera moves from Grace's face down her body to Robert's  hand, which rubs her good leg. He looks at her lovingly,  pushing the hair from her forehead. Annie, needing to do something, tenderly straightens Grac blankets. It is plain to see where her leg had once been. Robert can't look. Annie, one to face her fears, bravely  looks at it head on. She notices the I.V. Bag and rises o
That bag's almost empty.
(looking)
No, it's got a little left. They'll be  in to change it.
(as she exits)
Robert, you leave it up these people...! Robert is about to respond but Annie is already out the d We hear the O.S. DIALOGUE as Robert listens.
Excuse me, my daughter needs a new  I.V.
We have her down, we'll be right in.
I'd like it taken care of now please. Annie enters first.

You have to keep on top of these people  or else they just sit on their -- But Robert is ignoring her. Facing Grace, smoothing away hair. He's giving her the silent treatment. Annie knows t means Robert doesn't approve of her dictatorial behavior. Annoyed, she turns away as well. The Nurse enters with a new bag and begins to replace the one as Robert backs away.
I'm sorry.

Tch. What are you -- Annie, about to respond to his inappropriate politeness, stopped by Robert, who finally looks at her. It's a power look that tells her to calm down and shut up. It's a look that, for all of Robert's sensitivity, affects Annie. She gets the message and stays calm. As the nurse leaves, Annie is about to say thank you, but Robert beats her to it.
Thank you. Annie and Robert stand facing each other, when the PHONE Annie picks up.
LIZ HAMMOND on a cellular, walking away from the crowd.
Annie, it's Liz. How's Grace?
(journalistic)
Her leg was shattered so they had to,  uh... remove it. She had some bleeding  but it's under control.

Oh God, Annie, I'm so sorry. I... I  know you're being hit with a low now,  I don't want to take too much of your  time but I have to talk to you about  Pilgrim. Annie hears the name as if it's some distant echo she can quite identify; Liz speaks quickly as Annie watches Grace breathing in her sleep --

It's not good. I've never seen an animal  with these injuries still breathing. I  know this is difficult to hear right now  I'd like your permission to put him down.  It's the really best thing we can do for -- That was too much information for Annie;
Wait, uh, I, I don't understand. Start  again -- He's alive...
Yes, but he's in a tremendous pain...
Well, of course, right...
What is it?
(overlapping)
We really shouldn't wait...
(overlapping)
Hold on, Liz... (to Robert)
Something about Pilgrim... The Doctor pokes his head in.
(overlapping)
Mr. and Mrs. MacLean...
(overlapping)
-- put him down. She says...
(overlapping, to Doctor)
Yes. Hi. (to Annie)
Tell her you'll call her back. He exits with the Doctor.
Liz, listen, the Doctor's here and I  just can't, uh... talk now... so --
(interrupting)
I understand, but Annie, please...
(overlapping)
- See, what you can do for him --...
(overlapping)
Annie, no matter what I do, this horse  will never be the same.
... I just don't know right now! Do  whatever you can and when Grace is --
It isn't right to make him suffer...
And I can say the same thing about my  daughter! But she is suffering! Can you  solve that problem! (Liz is quiet)
I can't deal with this now, Liz! If you  need a yes or no right now, then no --  don't do it! Not until I know Grace is  all right. Now, please! Just do what you  can. Okay? (softer)
Please. Liz is stopped by Annie's almost pleading tone.
All right... They hang up. Annie takes a breath. Robert re-enters.
What did he say?
Nothing new. He's just going off duty. Beat. Silence.

I'm going to get all the nurses'  names... It's good to know all their  names. Robert nods. But neither of them moves. They stand motion for a beat, then Annie begins to break down and eases her into Robert's arms. Robert embraces her, kissing her head, with an almost fat comfort. His expression tells us it's the moment he's bee expecting... and wanting. Now she'll be all right, in his Whatever distance between them, whatever problems felt  insurmountable last night on the phone, are now, for the -- for Robert -- gone. But Annie's expression tells us something different. Her  instinct to hold him was honest... but the effect isn't t same anymore. Something doesn't feel right. Something isn working anymore about his comforting embrace.
I should go get some of her things.
No, let me go.
(gently pushing away)
No, I'll go. You stay... In case she  wakes up.

location: THE UNIVERSITY ANIMAL HOSPITAL, RECOVERY STALLS

text: A line of recovery stalls with various sick and hurt anim Liz, exhausted asleep, on a chair outside a stall. There' slight scratching sound. A hoof against the stall. It get louder, awakening Liz. She gets up and looks inside the  paddled stall: Pilgrim is lying in the stall, heavily bandaged. He is wa up. His first instinct is to kick at the paddled stall wa He looks at Liz, his eyes filled with madness -- enraged still be alive.

Annie opens the door and enters, flicking on the light.  Camera is on her back, as she places a small suitcase on bed and opens it. She begins her task with cool efficienc Opening drawers and closets, assessing what should be tak what isn't necessary. Suddenly, she stops. She feels disoriented for a moment. can't remember the last time she was inside this room. Sh takes a moment to pause and actually look around. In the light, we now see more of Grace's inner sanctum. H riding prize ribbons in various colors adorn the walls.  Books. A girl's bureau cluttered with teenage possession  ranging from childhood toys to items that suggest a reach towards adulthood. Annie examines some items, affectionat A GOOD LUCK CHARM from India sits among her things. Annie takes it to pack in the suitcase. She notices a framed 8X10 of Grace sitting proudly atop  Pilgrim with Judith at her heel. She then notices the edg another picture behind this one, in the frame. She pulls Pilgrim photo out to reveal: An old 8X10 of Annie hugging Grace as a toddler. With her back to Camera, Annie rememb
Annie is playing with toddler Grace. Chasing her around t room. Picking her and tossing her onto a small, toddler b Blowing into her stomach. Grace is laughing uncontrollabl
Annie slides the Pilgrim picture back into the frame, the returns to her task of packing.

Annie enters. No one else is there. She places the suitca on a chair and opens it. She takes out the INDIAN LUCKY C and some horse books, and places them on her bedside tabl She takes care to prop up the Lucky Charm. She wets a cloth with some water from a pitcher and gentl wipes Grace's sweaty brow... INSERT VISUAL FLASHBACK HERE instead of in Country House. Annie then continues unpacking the suitcase. She opens  Grace's closet and sees a hospital bag filled with Grace' clothes at the time of the accident. Annie examines them discovers they are hers. Annie shoves the clothes into a and starts unpacking.

The Clock is ticking on the wall. The cafeteria is empty  except for one tired Intern, drinking coffee on a break. Robert and Annie are having a cup of coffee. In the silen they search for things to say. Until:
I saw Judith's parents while you were  at the apartment... (Annie listens)
I wanted to say something... (beat)
But I... I was so relieved that Grace  was still... that it wasn't our daughter.
We're very lucky.
(nods)
The funeral's on Friday. He rises and crosses to the self-help coffee dispenser as continues...
Oh, uh, I meant to tell you... Alex  brought that fabric over...
Okay.
It's on the table by the phone. I didn't  know what to tell him... (returns to table, sits)
... Whether or not we were... (beat)
... if we still we're thinking of redoing  the couch. Annie just nods. She senses Robert is looking for some ki of reassurance, but she can't give it to him. He continue
... And uh... Mario called about moving  the wisteria?
Oh. Right. I'll call him. Pause. Annie looks at her husband as he stares off to the side, deep in his thoughts. She can sense he's sinking as fidgets with the napkins. She remembers:

A younger Annie stands in a bathrobe, noticeably pregnant cooking at a stove -- reading instructions from a propped cookbook. FRANK SINATRA IS BLASTING as she sings along, i full voice, without inhibitions;

head_text.subj: "SHE'S LOVES THE THEATRE BUT NEVER COMES
LATE... SHE NEVER BOTHERS WITH PEOPLE SHE
HATES... THAT'S WHY THE LADY IS A TRAMP

text: A younger Robert, wearing a suit, arrives home from work. her, he smiles affectionately. He puts down his briefcase bursts into his own playful Sinatra impersonation:
"She loves the free..." Startled, Annie turns around and smiles:
(sexily undoing his tie)

head_text.subj: "... FRESH, WIND IN HER HAIR... LIFE

text: (a la fan)
Sing it to me, Frankie!
(a la Sinatra cool)
How's my pregnant chick! She moves to him and they embrace... He wraps his arms ar her. They kiss. Annie laughs.
You can hardly get your arms around me.  How depressing. You're so early.
I had to excuse myself from a meeting.  It's ridiculous. I kept thinking about  the baby... you... and, I swear, I was  going to start bawling right into my  briefs.
(loving it)
Aw... that's so sweet.
I love you.
Do you? Do you really? They turn to each other and kiss. END OF MEMORY.
Annie and Robert sit silently at the table in an empty ho cafeteria, a lifetime later.

The room's lights are dimmed. Dawn is being to break thro Grace, slowly, opens her eyes coming out of sedation. She takes a moment to figure out where she is... to remember. She uses her hands to hoist herself up, but she's unstead and knocks into her bedside table -- knocking the Good Lu Charm from India off the table. It rolls under the bed, w a water tumbler. Grace never sees the Charm. Grace looks where her leg once was. She feels the blanket the empty space where her leg once was... just like her m did (did her father couldn't). Instead of self-pity, she' oddly fascinated.
Daylight pours in. Robert and Annie enter. Robert, loaded with gifts, immediately crosses to Grace, on the side of good leg. Annie takes her position beside the lost leg.  Robert kisses his daughter;
Hi, sweetheart... Annie's hand finds Grace's hand, and holds one of her fin tightly. Grace responds by wrapping her hand around her  mother's. They exchange a look of respect and gratitude.
Have you heard from Judith's parents?
No, not yet.
How's Pilgrim doing?
Liz is taking care of him. (to change the subject)
The doctor said the sooner you start  therapy the better the chances are you  can --
I can't even get out of bed yet! You're  already putting me in therapy!! Annie, slightly hurt, drops it as Robert takes over:

The doctor said whenever you're ready.  Take your time. You tell us... But he  thinks it'll only be a few months, then -- As Robert continues talking, Annie drifts to the Nurse.  Needing to manage something, she asks:
Did you get her fresh towels?

A limousine drives up as the Doorman gets the car door. T weather is slightly warmer. People's clothing looks as if spring is coming nearer. Annie exits first, carrying a jacket for Grace. She is  followed by Robert, who immediately turns to help Grace. hear her O.S.
Dad! I can do it, OK?!
Annie shoots him a disapproving look. We see Grace's good leg exit first... then two crutches,  followed by... a PROSTHETIC LEG. Grace scoots into view, takes a breath.
You all go ahead. I'll be up by  Christmas.
The three sit at a dinner table, eating dinner. Grace pic at her food. Robert can't help staring at her. Annie eats watching them both.
Do you want something else, honey?  We order something else?
No, I'm just not that hungry.
Why don't you go lie down?
I don't want to lie down. I've been  lying down enough.
You want to watch some television?
(edgy)
Maybe... look -- just... Robert and Annie wait. She doesn't continue. She rises,  reaching for her crutches. Robert moves to help.
I got it! I got it! She exits into her room. Annie looks at him disapprovingl
Annie and Robert stand before their separate sinks, talki to each other through their separate mirrors, as they was for bed.
You've got to stop doing that?
Doing what?

Helping all the time! Running to her  every time she trips or falls...  Anticipating her all the time. Robert shuts off his sink and dries his face, without a w He exits into the bedroom, and gets into bed. For a beat, stares up at the ceiling -- then says quite plainly.
You know, Annie, this didn't just happen  to you. Annie is applying moisturizer when she hears this. As it  sinks in, she doesn't like it.

Grace stands by her door and can hear her parents muffled tense voices. Annie is angry at his complacency. Robert j wants what's best for Grace. She closes the door. Silence She puts her crutches against the wall and tries to walk  towards her bureau without them. It is a struggle, but sh does... almost falling, but grabbing the bureau just in t The 8X10 of her and Pilgrim, falls face down. She props i and looks at it -- focusing on her horse, then on Judith. Suddenly, she lashes out, knocking the photograph onto th floor...
Honey, you all right? Did something  fall?
(angrily shouts)
Annie pulls up in a Range Rover and stops. Grace moves fo the door. Annie asks respectfully;
Do you want any help? Grace doesn't even bother to answer. She manages to get o the pavements, then turns for her bag... Annie notices other kids looking at Grace from behind, as enter the school.
Dad'll pick you up today, all right?
Okay. Grace looks up to her mother. What is unspoken between th is the understanding that today will be difficult and the nothing either one can do about it.
You'll be fine. Grace nods and turns to the school. Annie watches her go.

Grace makes her way through the hall. It is the first tim she has had to maneuver through a crowd. Some of the youn children are especially unconscious. Grace sweats her way through, trying to maintain her balance and her sanity. As Grace slowly moves along, whatever small faith she had that she could get through this day, begins to diminish.
Annie moves about the office, hands in pocket, in front o her wall of windows. LUCY and her staff sitting around th office. Annie is speaking to a YOUNG WOMAN staff member;

I don't care what he told you! The  man's a liar! The man's an actor, for  Christ's sake. They're all liars!  They'll say anything to get a cover... The Young Woman looks insulted. AN ASSISTANT comes in to Annie a note;
Annie is crossing an empty school yard. Grace is sitting the ground, her back against a wall, her "legs" in front her. She has been crying. She looks up to her mother.
It's too hard. Annie kneels before her sympathetically brushing her hair
Oh, honey... What happened?
Doesn't matter. I... I don't want to  come back, that's all.
(softly)
Oh. Well, what are you going to do? You  have to go to school, honey. I mean, what --
(snaps)
I'm not coming back! That's it! I want to  go home!
Grace, listen to me. Your body is just  healing. You have to give the rest of you  time as well...
Is that your version of a pep talk?
You are not staying home all day feeling  sorry for yourself. You're going to get  up and you're going to figure this out.
(snotty)
Fine!
It's still early. What's your next class? With secret delight, Grace viciously utters the word:
Gym!
Annie is at her desk studying Grace's book on Horse Whisp Robert is on his bed with briefs laid out before him.

The door is closed. A SONG blares on her stereo. Grace is her bed watching a video of her and Pilgrim... riding at horse show. There's a shot of Annie standing proudly,  watching her ride. Another shot of her and Judith, both o them on their horses, waving to camera.
Grace enters.
Dad? Both Robert and Annie look up.
What, sweetheart?
(beat)
I want to see Pilgrim. Robert and Annie exchange an anxious look.
It's raining. The MacLean car is parked by the barn. They are walking towards the stables under their umbrellas as runs to greet them.
Hello... (to Grace)
It's so good to see you. How ya  doing?
She's doing just grea. Aren't you  kiddo?
I'm fine.
Well, come on. He's out back now... (leads them)
Mind how you go. It's pretty muddy back  there.

Why is he in the back? Why isn't he in  the barn with the other horses? Liz stops, causing everyone to stop. She turns to face Gr realizing she doesn't know. She looks at Robert and Annie accusingly. She tries to explain:
Well, Grace, you see... Pilgrim just...  isn't the same horse he used to be. (to the parents)
As a matter of fact, maybe now's not  the best time to --

I really want to see him. Liz looks at Annie. Annie nods. Liz leads them on. They reach a row of empty old stalls. They cross to one o the stalls -- its doors are closed. Liz draws back the bo on top half of the door. There is an immediate explosion of sound inside the stall the sound of fear, startling them. Then it's still. Liz  slowly opens the door. Grace, with the aide of her cane,  walks to the stall. She hesitates, then looks in. It take moment for her eyes to grow accustomed to the dark. She s Pilgrim with his head down in the shadows...

Hello, beautiful boy... He lifts his head at the sound of her voice. Grace, and t audience, see him for the first time -- His mad eyes, his terrible disfigurement... Grace cries out, stepping backwards, nearly stumbling in mud... What is left of her horse are gone. Annie realizes what's happened and, together with Robert, rush to her... too see the monster Pilgrim has become and are horrified. Grace angrily pushes away from them and "runs" off. Rober goes after her. Annie is standing in the rain with Liz -- her eyes unable move away from the sight of Pilgrim.

You should have told her, Annie. I  tried to explain to you how bad it was...  I guess you had to see it. But, there's  nothing to be done. This animal's beyond  help. Annie, can I have your permission  now to put him down? Annie stands in the rain, hands in pocket, fixed on Pilgr and more determined than ever;
No.

Alone in her study, Annie sits before her computer search the Internet for information on HORSES -- Veterinarian  Journals, Therapies, Accidents, Eistories... We sense she been at it a while... She locates an ITEM TITLE -- HORSE WHISPERERS. Interested brings it up on the screen.
Annie sits in the huge reading room, books spread out bef her, under a green reading lamp. Her voice tells us what reading:
"It was in America that horses first  roamed..." In the books, we see pictures, lithographs, paintings and drawings...

"A million years before the birth of  man, they grazed the vast empty plains of  grass and crossed to other continents  over bridges of rocks... They first knew  man as the hunted knows the hunter, for  long before man saw horses as a means to  killing other beasts, man killed them for  meat..." ANNIE'S V.O. CONTINUES OVER;

"...The alliance with man would forever  be fragile -- for the fear he'd struck  into their hearts was too deep to be  dislodged... Since that Neolithic moment  when a horse was first haltered, there  were those among men who understood  this..."
Grace sits alone in her darkened room, staring out the wi but not looking at anything. There's a discomforting dist in her expression.
"... They could see into the creature's  soul and soothe the wounds they found  there..."
A hot, dusty fairgrounds horse arena. The worn wooden ble crowded. Lines of cars and pick-up trucks.

"...For secrets uttered softly into  troubled ears, these men were known as  The Whisperers..." One particular pick-up truck has its back door opened. A  MAN'S LEG is sticking out, putting on a pair of boots. A moment later the Man gets out of the car. Holding a cow hat, he has a certain quality, a self-respect, that men w know themselves seem to have. TOM BOOKER. A weathered redheaded woman named RONA -- late forties, s wiry horsewoman's build -- is walking towards him.
Hey, darlin'.
Hey, Rona. Sorry I'm late.
I wouldn't know what to do if you were  on time. They walk together towards the fairgrounds.
You're looking fit.
Fit? You want to check my teeth. (Tom laughs)
Good crowd today. I think you'll have  some fun. You going to stay for dinner?
If it's not too much trouble, I thought  I might.
(playful)
Kind of trouble I'm in the mood for.
Oh-oh... Maybe I better get back in the  truck. Rona lets out a hearty laugh as they enter the horse aren

Inside the corral, a small black thoroughbred is being wo by Tom. As he rides and narrates into a radio microphone the crowd, we sense this is a man of good humor and great skill --  guileless, sensible, of the earth.

... It's always kind of interesting to  hear the horse's side of the story... The crowd laughs warmly. He directs his comments to a WOM wearing an expensive Ralph Lauren western outfit, standin outside the corral...

Now if he was cranky or lazy, like you  say he is, we'd be seeing his tail  twitching there and his ears back,  maybe. But this isn't a cranky horse,  it's a scared horse. You see how braced  he is up around the neck back there.  He just doesn't know which way to turn... The Woman nods. Tom turns the horse on a dime so that he  always stays facing the circling thoroughbred...
You see how he keeps pointing his  hindquarters in at me? Well, I'd guess  the reason he seems reluctant to move  out is because when he does, he gets in  trouble for it.
He's not good at transitions, you know?  When I want him to move from a trot to a  lope, say...
(smiles)

Well, I'm sure that's what you think but  that's not what I'm seeing. You may think  you're asking for a lope, but your body  may be saying something else altogether.  You might be putting too many conditions  on him. For instance, you might be saying  "GO, but, hey, don't go too fast." He can  tell that from the way you feel. Your  body can't lie. You ever give him a kick  to make him move out?
He won't go unless I do.
And then he goes and you feel like he's  going too fast, so you yank him back? (she nods)
And next thing you know, he's bucking. (she nods again)
Well, if someone told you to go, stop,  go, stop -- you'd buck too. The people laugh. The Woman smiles self-consciously.

It's a dance, see... Somebody has to lead  and somebody has to follow. Tom gracefully moves his horse around the ring, "dancing" then takes up a long coiled rope and throws it so that th coils slap against the black horse's flank, making it bur into a lope. And again... Making the animal go from a tro a lope, letting it slow, then up to a lope again.

I want him to get so he can leave real  soft. He's getting the idea now. He's  not all braced up and tense like he was  at the start. He's finding out it's okay. He throws the rope again and this time the transition to lope is a smooth one.
You see that? He's getting better  already. Pretty soon, if you work at  it, you'll be able to make all these  transitions easy on a loose rein. (sotto voce, wry)
Yeah, and pigs'll fly. (to Woman)

He's going to be okay -- so long as you  don't go yanking on him. She nods, but he can see she's upset, feeling foolish. He walks the horse over to her, turns off the microphone and speaks sympathetically:
Look, the truth is it's all about self- preservation. These animals. (with great affection)

... well, they just have such big hearts,  you know? There's nothing they want more  than to do what you want them to do. But  when the messages get all confused, the  only thing they know to do is try and  save themselves... Now, why don't you go  saddle up and see what happens. Feeling better, and not a little attracted to his heartfe man's man, the Woman smiles and reaches for his hand to c over the rail. Her horse lets her come right up to him an stroke his neck. Tom comments;
They won't ever hold a thing against  you. They're the most forgiving  creatures God ever made. Turning on his mike and turning back to the crowd, he say
Okay, who's next? A Young Boy leads a mule into the ring. Tom smiles:
Now God has another idea entirely with  the mule.
Tom has finished his "show." People are shaking his hand, thanking him, as he walks away from the corral, towards a trailer. The Woman in the Ralph Lauren approaches:
Excuse me. He faces the Woman:

Hi. I'm Dale. I just wanted to -- I can't  get over the way he felt under me after  you'd finish with him. Everything had  just, I don't know, freed up or something. The Woman is flirting. Tom shrugs, uncomfortably;
Well, that'll happen.
Where did you learn all this stuff?
What stuff is that?
About horses? I'd love to learn more  about it myself. Do you offer any  private lessons for riders?
(getting the message)
Well... Dale... you know, a lot of this  stuff... it just... nuts and bolts.
What do you mean?
Well, if the rider's nuts, the horse  bolts. (smiles)
That's the whole lesson right there.  You have a good day now... Just... keep  on freeing yourself up. He leaves her, entering the trailer.
A small, well-used trailer. Tom and Rona are finishing di like comfortable old friends. Rona rises, taking the plat into the kitchen and starts rinsing them:
Oh I clear forget. You had a call from  some woman in New York. She sounded  pretty wound up.
I don't any woman in New York. But from  what I hear, most of them are wound up.

The number's by the phone. He nods but doesn't move. He just looks at Rona and smile She's a good woman. But Tom hopes she doesn't want anymor than what they have together. Rona notices him looking an smiles:
What are you looking at, young man?
How long were you married?
Long enough.
You ever miss it?
Does a horse miss a saddle?
Sometimes. She chuckles, shuts the water off and crosses back to him sitting beside him.
Well as a matter of fact, I don't... most  of the time. She starts unbuttoning his shirt.
You know, Rona, we weren't all that good  together even when we were good together.
Honey... I was always good. Tom smiles as Rona leans in. They kiss.
Annie is looking over a magazine cover with Lucy and her She is unhappy.

You know it's perfectly shot, it's  perfectly cropped, it's perfectly laid  out and I'm so bloody bored, I'd rather  buy a Motor Racing magazine -- Start  over. Some general whines and groans as her assistant hands her note.
Uh, would you all excuse me a moment? She waits for them to leave as she sits before the phone. of her lines is lit:

location: A ROADSIDE SERVICE STATION SOMEWHERE IN UTAH

text: An endless sky. An empty ribbon of two-lane highway in Ut A small roadside station. Tom's pick-up truck, his horse  trailer hitched to it, getting gas. Tom is on the pay phone. We hear Annie's voice:
This is Annie MacLean.
Yeah. Hello. This is Tom Booker. I got a  message you called. INTERCUT ANNIE in her office:
(efficient, expeditiously)

Oh! Yes. Thank you for calling back. Uh,  all right, let me try to explain my  situation as briefly as possible... You  see, my daughter had an accident with  her horse... They were both injured and  she, my daughter, she hasn't been able  to... fully... uh... It was an extremely  traumatic experience... and uh... Tom, sensing her turmoil, listening compassionately.

I went on the Internet and found this  article about you... It says you're a Horse  Whisperer, that you... you help people  with horse problems. And you have quite a  success rate when it comes to traumatized --
Well, see, truth is, ma'am, I help horses  with people's problems.

Well, you know, however you want to put  it -- I got your information from the  publisher of the article. I called  Montana and your sister-in-law, I think,  gave me this number. (trying to be charming)
I'm been hot on your trail you could say  because I was hoping you'd consider  coming to New York and taking a look at  my daughter's horse and possibly --
Ma'am, I'm very sorry about your problems  and I appreciate what your daughter must  be going through, but I'm afraid you've  misunderstood whatever it is you read. I  don't do that sort of thing.
Well, if you could just come for the day.  New York's only a few hours by plane,  I'd have you home by dinner...
Look, even if it was nearer, that's just  not what I do. I give clinics. And I'm  not even doing them for a while. I'm  heading back to Montana right now. I got  a ranch to take care of...
(interrupts, abruptly)
I'll pay you for your fare. I'll send you  to Montana first class.
(getting impatient)
Ma'am, first class to Montana is a waste  of good money. Now, am I being too polite  here or when I say NO in Utah, does that  mean YES in New York City? Annie is taken aback. Tom feels badly.

I, I don't mean to sound insensitive. I  understand your situation. But there's  nothing I can do. You just called the  wrong person, that's all. I hear there  are a bunch of therapists in New York.  Maybe you should call one of them.
Mr. Booker, if I could just ex --
I am very sorry, ma'am. Goodbye now. He hangs up before Annie can continue.
Annie reaches for Grace's bedroom door, then pauses. She  realizes she should knock. She does and whispers:
Grace? (knocks again)
Grace, it's mom. Annie slowly opens the door. She finds Grace's bed empty. looks over to the window to find Grace sitting in a chair the dark, looking out the window.
Grace. What are you doing? Not looking up, Grace speaks in a hollow voice.
I can't find that charm Daddy gave me  from India.
I brought it to you in the hospital.
No, you didn't.
Grace, I put it on the table near your --
(apathetic)
Doesn't matter. Beat.
Have you decided about Pilgrim?
What about him?
Well... how you feel all right about  telling Liz to put him down...
I think we should. It's not fair to let  him suffer. He's not much use anymore.  He'd hate living like that.
I think that's... very compassionate  and... mature way of looking at it.
Mom?
Yeah?
Maybe they should put me down too.
What?

I mean, I'm not much use anymore. Why  can't they be compassionate to me? What frightens Annie most is the calm and apathy in Grace voice. She's surrendering... Annie, for the first time in long time, feels she's losing control.
Annie sits alone at the kitchen table, nursing a glass of wine. Robert enters and sits opposite her, wearing a tuxedo -- tie and collar undone.
How was the dinner?
(wry)

All our "favorite" people were there  saying all their "favorite" things about  their "favorite" subjects. I thought to  myself, we've been friends with these  people almost twenty years and nobody  knows anybody. We're so afraid we won't  like each other and have nobody go to  dinners with.
Why did you go?
(surprised)
They're still our friends, Annie. It's  nothing serious. You kid about them all  the time... And I could tell Paul really  appreciated me being there. He drinks Annie's wine as she looks at him.
Did you get a hold of that horse guy?
Yeah.
What did he say?
No. Robert nods. Accepting. Silence. Annie sips her wine. The
I was thinking... Maybe we should think  about the three of us going someplace  warm... Remember that house we rented in  Bermuda... The pink one with the -- His arm accidentally spills the wine.

Shit. As he bends down to wipe it up with a napkin, Annie watch Robert clean the spill. Something about his movements, hi posture -- a sense of weakness, of surrendering, of not h the inclination to fight, of just accepting and smoothing over the rough sports -- strikes her hard. Annie realizes love she feels for Robert isn't fading. It's gone. He finishes cleaning and sits.
What was I saying?

About us going someplace warm...  Someplace Grace'll have to wear shorts  or bathing suits or summer dresses... Robert looks at her and realizes it's a bad idea. He nods again, getting the message. Silence. In that silence, Ann looks at him... and makes a decision:
Robert, I want to take Pilgrim out to Mr.  Booker. Drive him out to Montana... With  Grace. Robert is confused... and a little worried.
I don't understand. You just said he  said no.
He did, but... I think I can change his  mind.
That's the craziest thing I ever heard.  Absolutely not.
Robert, Grace isn't adjusting to school.  And she can't sit in this apartment all  day... I think it would be good for her.
(at a loss)
NO! What are you -- you're serious about  this?
I've called Liz. They can set me up with  a trailer for Pilgrim. I thought we'd  stay at motels along the way...
(overlapping)
You've already made arrangements!?
No. I was just researching. Calm down.
I come home and you tell me we're going  to drive a psychotic horse to Montana! I  can't just pick up and leave...
I'm not asking you to. I'll do it.
You want to do this by yourself? How?  You can't take care of Pilgrim all the --
He'll be sedated. I know horses, Robert.  I'm the one who taught Grace how to ride.
(overlapping)
What... Bo-... What about the magazine?

I'm in charge. I went back very soon  after the accident. They didn't expect me  for a couple of months. I'll just take  that time now... I can still oversee  things from Montana... Take my fax...  My computer... Beat. Robert fears this is about the marriage. Yet --
No. It's, uh... No, I really don't think  it's a good idea
Why?!
(searching)
Her psychiatrist... said... she needs  security now... stability...
I can't say he's been all that effective  with her.
Are you a psychiatrist? He said it takes  time.
I don't care what he says! We have to do  something, Robert! I can't sit here and  trust everything's going to work out just  by pretending it will.
I'm not pretending anything! Beat. Robert just stares at her. He looks concerned... al worried. Annie gets uncomfortable.
What? It is very difficult for Robert to say;
I thought... well, ever since the  accident, I just thought we... He stops. Annie knows where he headed and prays to God he doesn't continue. He doesn't. A thick silence hangs betwe them.
I really wish I could understand why  you think this is so necessary.
(frustrated)
Robert, we're losing her. We're losing  her. (he listens)

I don't care what the doctors say. The  truth is, they don't know anymore than  we do -- less, when it comes to Grace...  This may not sound sensible or... logical,  but nobody's suggesting anything better.  I can't explain it, Robert. I just have  this feeling... this annoying... bloody  feeling that if... if, somehow, Pilgrim  can be made all right... then so can Grace.  I just know it! Robert can feel the strength of her will. He can find no around it.
What if she doesn't want to go?
She will if you think she should.
And you think it's best if I don't come.
(hesitates)

No, that's not what I said. I'm not a  dictator. If you feel you should come,  then come. Just do whatever you think  is right. At some moment, they realize Grace is standing at the ent to the kitchen. They are surprised.
I'm not going! I don't care what she  says! Annie lowers her head. Robert stares at Grace as she walk him.

Daddy?... I don't want to go. Grace stands next to Robert. He holds her hands. Annie lo at him, without sympathy. Robert looks back. In his face the total acceptance of what must be. As well as the sadn of it's inevitability. He looks back at his daughter, who eyes have never left him.
Pilgrim is being loaded into the trailer by four strong s men, violently kicking and pulling all the way. Annie watches with anxiety -- an almost giddy Liz by her
Maybe we should give him another  sedative.
Problem is, there aren't many  volunteers. He's already had enough  to sink a battleship. You have a  pin, just in case?
Of course not.

Probably best. You may want to shoot  yourself half way to Ohio. In the back seat of ANNIE'S SUBURBAN sits Grace -- her ba the action. Hearing Pilgrim's struggle. Putting her walkm on her ears and raising the volume... We hear -- GRACE'S MUSIC, ON THE SOUNDTRACK, bringing us to:
Annie's Suburban drives along Route 80, pulling the horse trailer behind.

Grace, in the back seat, wearing her headphones, listenin her music (maybe LIZ PHAIR OR HOLLY COLE). Detached. Non- committal. As trucks pass by, their time slapping the pav she reacts and turns to the other window. Annie, in sunglasses, shifts her attention between the ro and her rear-view mirror -- checking on Grace.
The Suburban drives as the sun begins to set.
The Suburban and Horse Trailer are parked in the lot.

A small furnished motel room with two twin beds. Grace sits up in bed watching TV, with no expression. A s with canned laughter serves as a hypnotic drug. Annie enters from the bathroom, after showering, drying h hair. Grace doesn't bother to look up.
You want to take your bath? (Grace shakes her head)
We have to get up early tomorrow. You  may not have enough time to --
Fine -- I'll take my bath. She begins moving off the bed.
No, I don't mean you have to. It's just  that we may not have enough --
-- enough time tomorrow. I know.
Look, if you want to take it in the  morning, that's fine.
(interrupts on "fine")
I don't care. Annie realizes she may have pushed too hard, but she also realizes there's no talking to Grace now. So, she achieve her goal --
Take it now. Grace hobbles off the bed, enters the bathroom and shuts door.

The lights are off. Annie lays in bed, wide awake. It is middle of the night. Grace, asleep in the other bed, begins whimpering. She's  having a bad dream. Annie rises -- considering whether or to intercede... Finally, Grace begins to cry out... softl first, but with increasing intensity until she awakens in fear... Annie appears right by her side.
What, sweetheart? What? Shaken, Grace cannot fight how much she needs her mother that moment. She wraps her arms around her, tightly, and to catch her breath.
It's sleeping in a strange bed,  that's all. Happens sometimes. It's  Ok. It's OK.
The Suburban continues its journey. Once again -- Annie, in the front, and Grace, in the rear drive without a word between them.
Grace and Annie occupy their same positions. Annie is on car phone with her office.

Okay, listen -- let's do this. When  I get to the next motel, I'll see if  they have a fax. If not, I'll call  you tomorrow to -- Annie continues O.S. when we hear a shifting, a rocking i the trailer behind them. As if Pilgrim made a sudden move Grace quickly turns her head. Annie looks in the rear vie Grace.
Uh Lucy, look, I have to go. OK...  Later. Annie hangs up and smiles at Grace through the mirror. Gr reaches for her walkman and headphones. Annie offers;
Grace! GRACE! Grace lowers one side of her headphones;

Would you like to put your music on  up here? Grace shrugs. Annie shrugs it off as well. Grace replaces headphone. Annie turns on the radio -- nothing but countr gospel or religious talk shows... She shuts it off. Frust Annie looks up ahead and sees:
Annie yells to be heard through the headphones;
(shrugs)
Whatever you want.
Fine!
Fine. Annoyed, Annie pulls onto the gravel and stops, talking t herself --
Fine! She exits the car, banging the door. As she walks acrund car to help Grace, she talks to herself in a sarcastic wh

"Whatever you want!" Well, this is what  I want. I want to eat lunch and I want  to smoke a cigarette and I want to keep  talking to myself for the next two  thousand fucking miles..."! She opens Grace's door. Grace senses her mother's anger.

Annie and Grace enter. They look around: Formica floors, truckers in caps and beer bellies stuffed into booths or at the counter. There is not a single spac available. Annie and Grace stand near the entrance. Another Trucker  enters and they step aside, huddled together in this fore land.
Grace and Annie enter the room to find A DOUBLE BED inste of two twins. Neither comments. Annie exits O.S., carrying the bags inside, as she says:
You should call your dad before it  gets too late.
I already did. (Annie's surprised)
This morning. When you went running.
Oh. You didn't tell me.
I didn't know I had to.
(stares angrily, speaks  softly)
You don't. Silence. Annie exits past her to the car.

Grace is asleep in her twin bed. Once again, Annie is wid awake. The clock reads: 4:55 AM. But Annie can not sleep. Camera moves away from Annie, past her side of the bed, t the other side of the room. WE SEE THE SHADOW OF A WOMAN coming towards the bed. She  comes in camera angle and we follow to her back to the be which has now transformed into --

head_text.subj: A BED FROM THE PAST, IN WHICH A TEN-YEAR-OLD ANNIE IS
SLEEPING WITH HER YOUNGER BROTHER GEORGE.

text: The Woman gently shakes little Annie awaken.
Annie... Annie, sweetheart... wake  up. The little girl, with sleep in her eyes, turns and sees h
Bad news I'm afraid. Your Daddy's  gone. END OF MEMORY. Annie, in present time next to Grace, thinks of this as s stays awake. Putting her jogging parka on over her nightg she goes outside.

She crosses the motel parking lot to the horse trailer. S looks in through the siding at Pilgrim, checking on him. sees he is caught his halter on the side of the van. She  crosses to the trailer door, hesitates, then opens it.  Pilgrim looks at her. Gathering her courage, she climbs  inside. He is still, looking at her. She carefully frees halter. And suddenly he bares his teeth, biting at her. S stumbles back out of the trailer, slamming the door shut. stands leaning against the trailer -- wondering if she's of her mind for attempting this.

Annie is returning from her jog, sweating. As she crosses her motel room, she stops by the window, looking in to se Grace, on the floor, straining to do her exercises. Annie fills with compassion for her girl -- reminded of t struggle she faces everyday.
In the distance, the Suburban and horse trailer look like dot on the horizon, moving across the Badlands.

Grace leans against the window in the back, in one of her darker moods. Annie switches radio stations, from Bible  thumping to Farm reports. She shuts it off. Silence. She sees a ROAD SIGH: "LITTLE BIGHORN NATIONAL MONUMENT".
Grace, look! Grace reads the sign.
Would you like to see that?
I don't care.
(overlapping)

I don't care. Annie's comic mimicking, throws Grace off center. Annie turns off onto the exit. They drive by a massive ca -- it's neon sign flickering. They drive up a hill past a two Indians in high crowned Cowboy hats standing outside the cafe. She drives up a hill towards the parking lot of Monument...
This'll be nice. We haven't seen any  of the sights yet. It's history. When  I was thirteen I used to love seeing  things like this.

You were never thirteen, Mom. Annie laughs, taking it as a joke. Grace almost smiles. But, Annie drives up to sign only to find a CLOSED SIGN. park was closed at six. Annie stops the car. She's hit a  brick wall once more. Silence. Finally, Grace speaks with usual sarcasm;
Great idea. So now what? Beat. Annie's patience snaps;
How long is this going to go on?
What?
You know what I mean? (turns to the back seat)
Is this it now? Is this the way we're  going to be from now on? Ignoring her, Grace edges to the passenger side and exits car. Annie gets out of the driver's side and walks around she speaks:
Do you want us to turn around and go  back home? Do you?
What are you asking me for? You didn't  ask me if I wanted to come in the first  place -- now I get to decide? Forget it! She begins to turn away. Annie grabs her arm.
Who do you think I'm doing this for?  I'm doing this for you!
Bullshit! It's about you! About you  deciding! About you always being  right! You always getting everything  your way, controlling everybody --  like we work for you or something!
I don't believe this!
You just want to get away from Daddy  and you're using me to do it!
That's not true! Whatever problems your  father and I are having, have nothing  to do with this.
You're amazing! You act like I don't  live in that house! Don't you think I  hear the two of you!? Don't you think  I can tell what's going on? I'm not  five years old, Mom! (Annie is stopped)
You want to divorce Daddy and Daddy  doesn't want to.
Did he tell you that?
He doesn't have to! It's, like, so  obvious you can't stand him.
That's not true!
Then why do you want to leave?
It's... it's not that simple to explain.  I know you think it is, but it's not.  The truth is, I don't really know what  I want to do. I don't have all the  answers.

No, you just act like you do. Annie is choked with fury. She doesn't know whether to  scream, cry or strangle Grace. She turns away and begins  walking quickly, blindly, up past a grove of trees. She c to a CEMETERY enclosed by a black railing. At the crest o the hill there's a stone monument "The Little Bighorn  Cemetery." In the growing darkness, she sees, scattered on the hills below her, white tombstones. A place of sorrow. A cool br ruffles her coat and she sticks her hands in her pockets. Frustrated, alone, at a complete loss as to what to do, w action to take -- Annie, for the first time in frozen,  standing still -- and with her, comes a rush of emotion. She sits with her back against the monument and begins to weep. For Grace, for Robert, herself, for the tombstones, everyone. A FLASHLIGHT shines on her face. It is a PARK RANGER.
You okay, ma'am?
(wipes face)
Yes. Fine.
That young lady is getting a little  worried. Annie realizes she left Grace alone as it got darker.
I'm sorry. I'm sorry... Annie rises and is escorted back to the Suburban by the  Ranger. She sees: Grace is sitting in the front seat now, waiting for her - like a little girl lost.
Annie gets into the driver's seat. Buckles up. Grace hold back tears.
You buckled up? (Grace nods)
You cold?
Little. Annie reaches into the back seat and pulls a blanket out, handing it to Grace, making sure it covers her. Grace tur towards the window and closes her eyes. Annie starts the
C.U. on Pilgrim's head in the trailer as we PULL BACK to  reveal the Suburban coming down an empty, seemingly infin stretch of two-lane road in Montana.
Annie and Grace, both in front seats, eating doughnuts an coffee. They stop. POV -- Through the windshield is an endless sky and a rol sea of land.
Gee, this looks like a fun place.
Don't they believe in signs here?
What would they say? "Ten miles to big  rock." "Twenty miles to bigger rock."
There was supposed to be a turn off.  Did I miss it?
I didn't see it. Their Suburban is the only vehicle on what seems like mil of road. Annie sighs and puts the Suburban in drive.

The Suburban and the horse trailer, pulls into Peterson's collection of motel cottage adjacent to an expanse of lan that includes stable, corral, a main house and various ri trails into the mountains. Mr. Peterson runs out from the main house to greet Annie she gets out of the car.

location: SUBURBAN, ON ANOTHER MONTANA BACK ROAD

text: Annie, showered and changed, is trying to follow Mr.  Peterson's directions to Tom's ranch -- written on Peters motel stationary. She is lost once again.
(reading)
... after left, stay on main road until  rise, then... (frustrated)
What bloody rise?!? What main road!? She stops the Suburban (no longer carrying the trailer).
From outside the Suburban, we see, but cannot hear, Annie hitting the steering and cursing in frustration.

Annie, panting, looks ahead and sees nothing but empty sp above and below -- as if the earth and sky met with nothi between. She sighs and starts the car again. As she moves forward, senses an almost indistinguishable rise in the road -- as follow her POV up the road through the windshield to reve POV -- A BREATHTAKING VALLEY just beyond the rise, hidden from view only a few yards before. THE DOUBLE DIVIDE RANC sits nestled in the valley, a few miles away. Annie is  impressed.

Men are working in the corral, saddle horses standing nea trying to get a sick calf to suckle a cow. One of the men Tom Booker, working along side his brother FRANK, and his nephew, JOE. Frank is a good man -- solid work ethic,  Christian fearing, wry sense of humor. With the build of football player, his strength never overwhelms his boyish good-natured heart. Joe is eleven, wearing his cowboy hat like a badge of honor. The three men seem as inseparable each other, as they are to the land. As they work:
Can we take a look at Bronty's foal  when we're done here, Dad?
Sure. As long as she don't mind.
There's a kid at school says we  should've imprint-trained him. Tom and Frank don't say anything. Just nod, knowingly.
He says if you do it soon as they're  born, it makes them real easy to handle  later on.
That's what some folks say.
There was this thing on the TV about a  guy who does it with geese. He has this  airplane and these baby geese all grow  up thinking it's their mom, and he flies  it and they just follow. (to Tom)
You hear 'bout that, Uncle T?
Yeah, I hear about that.
Well, what do you think about that  stuff?

Well, Joe, I'll tell ya -- I don't know  a whole lot about geese. Maybe it's okay  for them to grow up thinking they're  airplanes. But horses, as far as I can  tell, can't fly. Frank laughs. Joe smirks as Tom messes his hat up. There' sound of a car. They turn. The Suburban is coming over the ridge, heading down the  driveway in a cloud of dust.
We expecting company? Frank shakes his head. As the Suburban slows down, Tom  recognizes the driver.
I don't believe it.
You know her? Annie, out of her element, hiding behind sunglasses, gets as Tom approaches her by himself. Annie girds herself for confrontation.
Hello, Mr. Booker. Annie MacLean. From  New York. We talked on the phone. She extends her hand. TOM shakes it, nodding, staring at curiously.
It's, uh... beautiful country. I had a  little bit of a hard time finding the  place. There are no signs.
Plenty of signs -- just none of them  printed. Who do I get the idea you're  not just passing through!
Well... OK... here it is... Uh... I'd  like you to take a look at my horse.  Now -- it won't take long and if, after  that, you still don't feel...
Were you thinking of personally driving  me back East?
Oh no. She's here. I brought him along.  And my daughter, too. We're staying at  Peterson's...
You mean you hauled him all the way out  here? Just like that?
(slightly taken aback)
Well... yes... I had a trailer. It's not  like I made him run along side of the car.

All by yourself? She nods. Tom cannot help be impressed by her guts and fo Camera cuts away for a moment to a window in the ranch ho through which DIANE -- Frank's fiery, loyal pioneer wife looks at the duo with suspicion.
I uh... ha, ha... I don't think I ever  met a lady quite like yourself and I  appreciate all the pains you've gone  through to --
Look! Please! Don't do the "shucks,  ma'am" thing again! (Tom, surprised, listens)
I've driven a few thousand miles for a  few minutes of your time. I've brought  him here -- to your neck of the... (seeing no woods)

-- mountains. Just take a look at him.  If you still feel the same way, I'll  be on the road by morning and you'll  never see me again. OK? Deal? Tom tries to hide a smile of respect. Annie, thinking she have him, starts backing away towards her car -- as one w a dangerous animal they think they might have tamed...
We're at Peterson's. Whenever you're  free. You don't even have to call. She gets into the Suburban. Tom watches her drive off.
Tom walks up some wooden steps to a door and knocks. He h a TV on inside. And Grace's Voice:
MOM! The door! He hears Annie's muffled reply from O.S. He hears some ba as Grace fumbles for her crutch and comes to the door. Sh opens it only so far as to reveal her upper body:
Yeah?
Uh, I'm Tom Booker. Your mother  around? Grace hops to the side as Tom walks by her, into the room Grace is closing the door as he turns to see, for the fir time, that Grace is one leg.

She'll be right out. She's on the  phone. Grace hops back to the bed in front of the TV. Tom nods a puts his hat down -- noticing the prosthetic leaning agai the window, near her bed. He hears Annie on the phone and looks to the other room, the door ajar -- seeing only her legs, seated on the edge of her bed, as she talks. Her fo taps impatiently.
First time in Montana? Grace, rudely nods, still looking at the TV. Beat. Tom doesn't like her manner, but can easily see thr it. He sits.
She gonna be long?
Probably. She's on the phone twenty- three hours a day.
What does she do?
She's an editor.
Mmm. An editor.

Not like books or literature or anything.  Just a magazine... Just in case she  hasn't told you -- which I'm sure she  hasn't -- I don't want to be a part of  this, OK? Tom just sort of nods. A beat or two later, Annie enters.
Sorry about that. Hi. Grace, this is  Mr. Booker... Have you looked at  Pilgrim? Tom sees Grace turn away, just as Annie enters. He takes moment. He could say no right there, but something stops
Uh, no. I was gonna take a look now.
You want us to come with you? I just  have to run to the main house and give  Mr. Peterson a check.
Doesn't matter.
Grace?... Grace, you want to come with  us, take a look at Pilgrim? Grace keeps looking at the TV. No reply. Tom is half way the door when he says to Annie -- making sure Grace can h

Probably best she stays behind, anyway. He disappears. Annie gives Grace a final look and exits, Alone, Grace flings her body across the bed, reaching for prosthetic -- putting it on feverishly. She is completely intrigued by Tom.
Tom stands alone at the stable. Opening the bottom door,  ducking under the stall, he goes inside.

Okay now... Okay now... Walking towards him, Tom raises his hand, showing Pilgrim sign of respect, of trust... He quietly makes his way alo Pilgrim's side, along his flank, prompting Pilgrim to mov out from the shadows, into the light. Tom moves to look a him. And Pilgrim suddenly kicks out at him. Tom, not cowe stands his ground. He bends, looking at Pilgrim's withere legs. He looks up at his scarred head. He looks into the  pools of the horse's tortured eyes. Pilgrim stands still allowing Tom this brief intimacy. As Grace walks towards the stable, she realizes that the is open and Tom must be inside. She is amazed. Annie, appearing behind her, is also impressed. Tom exits the stable and sees them, as he closes the door

Well... You're closest anyone's  gotten. He walks straight towards them -- veering more to Grace. stops in front of her and they look into each other's eye in a way that reminds us of how Tom looked at Pilgrim. Except, Grace is made even more uncomfortable by the inti She turns away and walks to the corral, to lean on a post as if she doesn't care. Tom turns to Annie.

I have to be honest. I still feel  you made a long trip for nothing. He looks at Annie. Annie has no more words -- just an eve present pleading in her face. Tom watches as Grace makes a small, naked movement -- put her hand on her cheek, like a hurt child. He can't help but see these three being connected by one
But before I even think about it, I  need to know something here and now.  It's a question for Grace here. Grace stiffens.
When I work with a horse, it's no good  just me doing it. It doesn't work that  way. The owner needs to be involved too.
Well, that'll be a little complicated --

You can make it as complicated or as  easy as you like. But she's the one  who's gonna be riding him, am I right?  So here's the deal. I'm not sure I can  do anything, but I'm prepared to give  it a go -- (to Grace)
-- if you'll help. (Grace gives a bitter laugh)
You have a problem with that?
Isn't it like, obvious?
Not to me. Either you want to or you  don't.
Look, I'll talk to Grace and call you  later--

Excuse me, with all due respect, but  this is her decision, not yours. And I  don't want to waste anybody's time --  mostly mine. Grace reacts anew to Tom's remark. She likes her mother b dis-empowered. Annie keenly understands the importance of putting it this way to Grace. Grace has all eyes on her - just what she wants. All waiting for her response. She tu away, flicks her head and says:
Well, there's nothing else to do around  here. Annie smiles in relief. But Tom isn't satisfied.
Not good enough. I can't help you. He starts walking away. Annie doesn't know what to do. Gr mumbles.
What do I have to do? Tom keeps walking out... Grace says it louder.
I said, what do I have to do?! Tom stops and looks at her. Annie holds her breath.
Frank, Tom, Joe and TOM TWIN BOYS, 6 years old, sit at a table eating dinner, as Diane serves. We parachute into t middle of the conversation:
... well, I just think she's got a lot  of nerve showing up here. Draggin' that  child and that poor animal all the way... (TO ONE OF THE TWINS)
You eat with those fingers again and you  know what'll happen! (the boy cowers)
Frank, don't you think she's got a nerve?
Oh hell, I don't know... According to Tom,  she's a pretty determined woman. Must've  thought it was worth it.
(sits down)
I guess they'll want feeding and all, out  here all day long.
I don't believe they'll expect that.
What, they ain't going forty miles into  Choteau everytime they want a hamburger.
Mixed salad.
What?
(slyly)
I believe women from New York eat mixed  salads. Ain't that right, Tom? Tom hides a grin -- he knows Frank into teasing her now.
I believe so. Saw it on a television  show, once.
Well, that's just what we need on a cattle  ranch -- a vegetarian from New York. Everyone eats. Beat.
When you figure on branding?
Weekend after next...
If the weather holds. Frank nods. Silence again. Everyone eats. Beat.
What's an editor do anyway?
(playing)
We're not sure, sweetheart, but they  eat like rabbits. Tom and Frank chuckle. Diane smiles -- in on the joke wit them. The children are curiously confused.
Camera moves to reveal Annie on the phone in front of her computer and fax...  plugging in extension cords as she t

... the phone company's putting in extra  lines. I'll call back with the numbers.  Oh, and I want you to get in touch with  this lady in town here -- they say she's  sort of a physical therapist for the  rodeo boys but keep the one at the  hospital we already contacted on call... Grace sits alone in the living room. Watching TV, but anx and disturbed about what she's committed herself to.

Diane is in her bathrobe doing bills at the kitchen table she listens to a BOOK OF TAPE. Her hand on her forehead, other hand writing. Tom enters to take his hat off the  sideboard. He moves to the table and reaches over for a  cookie from a plate of cookies. Without looking up, Diane slaps his hand. Tom then pours himself a cup of coffee... swiftly sneaks his hand back and grabs a cookie. Diane sm Tom exits. It is only then that Diane looks up after him.

Camera follows Tom towards his bedroom --  passing the ot Perhaps we see Frank sprawled out asleep already in his  underwear. We might see the Twins in their bunks. One of Twins' lower torso is laying outside of the blanket. He  casually flips the blanket over the kid's bare feet and  continues to his room.

Tom enters and closes the door. Turns on a stereo which p a cello piece by Yo-Yo Ma. Books fills his room. He sits his desk, puts on eye glasses and looks through some pape Suddenly he stops, looking over the paperwork, into space thought passes by. We don't know what.

First light of day. Pilgrim stands stock still in the mid of the corral. Tom, motionless, is crouched on his haunch in the corral -- watching him. TOM'S POV: As Pilgrim moves, he can see that the horse is stove up. He softly tosses a handful of dirt at Pilgrim's withered  legs... Pilgrim, sensitive to the slightest provocation,  bucks, wheeling away from him. Then stops. Tom sits on hi haunches again... and watches him. Frank appears, exiting from the barn (perhaps).
Tom?
Yeah. Tom leaves Pilgrim, hooking up with Frank -- the two brot go off, discussing the ranch work that is ahead of them.

Annie and Grace arrive in the Suburban. They exit. As the head towards the ranch, they see in the distance: Pilgrim standing along the fence of a round pen. Tom stan in the pen, holding a rope, looking at Pilgrim.

Tom stands in the pen with Pilgrim. He looks to see Annie Grace approaching but makes no acknowledgement. He turns focus back to Pilgrim. Annie and Grace appear. Grace takes a position (that is t become her regular spot) a distance away from the pen. An moves in closer, beside SMOKEY (a ranch hand) with one le up on the pen fence.
Howdy... (sees Grace)
Howdy. He and Annie watch as Tom stands before Pilgrim -- turnin sideways... then standing...
What's he doing?
Trying to get his eye.
How's it going? Smokey doesn't respond -- how it's going is exactly how i looks. Tom takes a few steps, stops and stands still agai sense the process is long and requires great patience.

Two hours later. Grace is in the same spot. Smokey is gon doing his work. Annie has taken a different position, loo over SEVERAL PAGES OF FAXES on her lap. Tom is still standing in the pen trying to get Pilgrim's Joe has joined the proceedings, sitting on the pen rail. Tom deftly throws a hoolihan, gently lassoing Pilgrim aro the neck. And Pilgrim, at the touch of the rope, crazed,  resists, pulling back, striking at the rope... The rope  cutting into Tom's hands. Tom gives him some slack, givin his head, letting him relax... then gently heads him by t rope, walking him around the pen, getting his feet to mov Grace's eyes never leave Tom.

Tom, off in the distance -- against a sky that seems to b touching the land -- is riding along a creek. Closer up, see he's rustling the bushes with a stick. Some stray cow run out of the bushes. Tom races after them. His horse  shepherds the cow across the creek and up a hillside. At the top of the hill, with the ranch spread out endless before him, Tom sees Frank on his horse, chasing strays. whistles. Frank waves back. In the near distance, a picku truck is parked on the range. Joe and the TWINS are throwing food pellets out of the ba of the truck. Cattle come from across the range for the f What begins as a handful of cows becomes dozens, then  hundreds -- the truck virtually disappearing among them. Tom stops for a moment to look out at his ranch. Far off the distance, he sees Annie's Suburban coming along the r to the ranch. He watches as Annie's distant figure gets o of the car with Grace. Annie instinctively turns and look across the land. Even though there is such a distance,  there's a sense Tom and Annie are looking at each other. Tom senses Joe driving Frank's truck, slowly moving off t range -- the Twins in the back, the cattle following. Tom on his horse atop the hill.

Pilgrim, his scarred head above water, legs moving in odd sycopation, swimming. We discover he is in a pond, tether to a pole...
