Except for the sound of his legs in the wate everything is quiet and focused on Pilgrim. SMOKEY, holds the pole, walking on the outside of the pon leading Pilgrim back and forth as he swims. Tom, crouched the pond, silently concentrating on Pilgrim... Grace watches, off by herself... Annie stands beside Joe. can't help but be intrigued by the sight. She asks Joe;
I though horses were afraid of  water? Joe doesn't answer her. Grace likes that. Annie, frustrat feels she has the right to simple shout out to Tom.

Is that to get his strength back? Tom pays her no mind -- concentrating on Pilgrim. Suddenly, Annie's CELL PHONE rings, jarring the proceedin Tom turns to Annie. She hides her embarrassment by answer it, walking away. Tom gives her a look. Grace is loving t Tom turns back to Pilgrim. After a few moments -- Tom, taking the rope tether, unhooks it from the pole. He starts to lead Pilgrim out of the water. Pilgrim, fearful fights him. He rears, splashing Tom, not wanting to come of the water. Grace is worried. She looks to Joe and sees is concerned too, though he stands quietly. Annie hears the commotion from where she stands and finis her call to return to the pond. Tom enters the pond, waist deep in water, trying to grab  Pilgrim's rope. Pilgrim rises up, rearing at him. Joe and Smokey, sensing danger, come closer to the pond. Annie  appears beside Grace and watches as Tom reaches for the r again. Pilgrim rears again. Tom stumbles backwards from h hooves. Annie gasps. Grace turns to walk away from the po She can't watch -- it brings back too much. But as she do she is stopped by the sight of -- Tom, righting himself, unphased, calmly walks back to Pil The horse, baffled by this man's lack of fear, lets him t the rope and walk him out of the pond. Grace can't help but be impressed. Joe nods. Annie is sha
Mr. Booker, I'm not at all comfortable  with you taking those kinds of chances... As Tom leads Pilgrim out, the horse suddenly whirls, bolt knocking Tom down...
Oh, God! Pilgrim runs off, pulling the wet rope behind him. Joe ru over and grabs for the rope.

Joe obeys. Pilgrim runs past the corral and down into a h out onto a pasture, He keeps on running into the distance running across the pasture, not knowing where he is going Tom, arms folded across his chest, watches him run. A  concerned Annie approaches.

She's running away! How are you going  to get him back? Tom doesn't respond. He walks off down the hill out onto pasture, stops, arms folded and watches Pilgrim. Annie tu when she hears Smokey, who appears behind her:
He don't really want to run. Don't  know where he's going. All this open  space scares the daylight out of him. Confused, Pilgrim stops running and walks, in no particul direction.

My guess is he's spent his life in a  six-by-eight stall... He's forgot what  it's like to be a horse... Smokey ambles off and she turns back to see Tom crouching his haunches, sitting in the grass, just waiting. Pilgrim walks back towards the ranch, stops a distance from Tom,  looks at him... Annie, needing to know exactly what's goi on, crosses down the hill to him.

So what now? Should we leave? Tom continues watching Pilgrim. Annie looks at him, sitti there motionless and feels like an idiot. Clearly she doe understand all this and clearly no one thinks this is the time to explain to her.

Well, we're going to go then... Without looking at her, Tom just nods. Annie, awkwardly,  walks back up the hill to where Grace is... ON THE GRASSY HILLSIDE, Grace is watching the scene by he as Joe appears, staring at her leg... It makes her uncomf She turns to him with a curt, impatient tone;
What? Their eyes meet. Joe is so guileless, Grace is taken off when he asks in such a compassionate voice;
Does that hurt you? Grace tries to think of an answer -- and of how to say it
Only when I kick somebody. Her gentle delivery makes him smile. She smiles, then:
Don't you go to school?
Twice a month they give you a day off  to work on the ranch. He tips his hat down as he looks out to Pilgrim with resp
Look at him out in the pasture -- Yeah,  he must've been a big, beautiful looking  horse. How was he to ride? Grace is uncomfortable again. She looks away, just strugg Joe senses she's done talking;
Excuse me. I got chores to look after. He tips his hat and walks off, passing Annie as she arriv
You ready to go? Grace hesitates. Then mother and daughter take one more l POV -- Pilgrim standing in the pasture with Tom crouching the grass waiting for him.
Tom is still sitting in the grass, just where we left him waiting patiently. Pilgrim is still out in the pasture.

Afternoon shadows cross the ranch. Tom is in the exact sa spot and position. Pilgrim is somewhat closer -- but stil a distance -- watching him. Frank rides back from work. As he passes Tom, the two nod if nothing usually is going on. Frank rides up to the bar
Grace is flicking the television -- repeating the only th channels over and over... Annie works at her computer, surrounded by work. She noti the time, gets a thought and dials the phone...
Hello, Mr. Booker... Oh, hello, Frank.  This is Annie MacLean... I was  wondering, has-... (listens)
Uh-huh... And Pilgrim?... (listens)
Still?... Uh-huh... (politely cheery)
Okay then. Thank you. She hangs up, pauses, then speaks to the window out loud for Grace to hear --
He's still sitting in that damn  field.
(w/o looking at her)
I think they call it a pasture. Annie looks at her as if to say the last thing I need to a lesson on the local lingo...
Let's go see what's going on, then  get something to eat.

The sky is changing colors, the temperature has dropped. is still sitting in the grass, although someone has broug him a blanket for his shoulders. Pilgrim is in the pastur but now -- he too is motionless, looking back at Tom. The sound of a car makes Tom turn to see Annie driving up She gets out, stands by the car with a proprietary air,  watching Tom and Pilgrim. Grace remains in the car. There sound. She turns to see Diane coming out of the house...
There's coffee inside... I was just  bringing this to Tom.
Would you mind if I did? I'd like to  talk to him. Diane, knowing full well Tom ain't in a talking mood, han her a cup...
Sure. (seeing Grace in car)
Does your daughter want to come  inside?
Uh, no, we're going to dinner... Is  this the way to the pasture?

Pasture? Oh, that stretch of field near  the hill? Yeah. She's gone. Annie grimaces, then crosses the hillside to  where Tom is squatting down. She appears to his side and, without speaking, tries to indicates she has his coffee b leaning it toward him. Tom sees her and accepts it with a grateful nod. Annie waits. Nothing happens. Feeling fooli she begins to walk back. At some point, she turns to see Pilgrim moving across the pasture toward Tom. He stops in front of him, just a few away. Tom says something to him. Annie is intrigued -- an knows enough to stay quiet now. She watches Pilgrim walk to him. She watches as Tom gets up and pats Pilgrim's sca head. In spite of herself, Annie is somewhat moved by thi Only we see Grace, peering out from the car, seeing this of communion as well. Only we see her reaction to it. As Tom turns and walks back to the ranch, Pilgrim follows As he passes Annie, all he says is...
From now on, leave your phone  somewhere else... As he moves past her, Annie responds;
But I have business calls I have  to -- Tom keeps heading for the barn as he suggests, without tu back;

Then drop off Grace in the morning,  go on back and do your business.  Come pick her up around dinner. Standing there, Annie has the impulse to respond to this  suggestion, but has no idea what to say and saying it wou make much sense since Tom is already out of ear shot. Diane appears from the house and calls out:
Mrs. MacLean -- why don't you and  daughter stay for dinner?
Oh uh, thank you. No, we don't want to  impose.
No imposition. Plenty of food. Gonna  get pretty dark soon. Hard to find a  place. Annie looks up to the alien sky and realizes she's right. looks to Grace, who doesn't seem to oppose the idea.
Everyone sits around the kitchen table. Joe, still wearin his hat, eyes Annie and Grace with acute curiosity.

Joe, take off the hat -- I'm not  going to say it again. Joe obeys. Diane puts the last of the serving plates on t table -- pork chops, potatoes, gravy, peas, bread... And bowl of mixed salad. The boy can't help eyeing how the  "vegetarians" will act. Annie and Grace eye the food. Annie reaches out for a ser ladle, picking up Grace's plate to serve her as Grace rea for a piece of bread, when:
Dear Lord, we are humbly thankful  for... Annie and Grace freeze as Frank continues his prayer -- t notice everyone's head bowed slightly.
(continues)
these gifts. For the blessings on our  home, our family and our guests. Bless  those that aren't as fortunate. Bless  all God's creatures.
Amen. Everyone begins eating. Annie and Grace breath a sigh of Silence. Utensils hitting plates, the only sound.
Bank out us a couple more men to run  the cattle.
We should be fine, then. Beat. Annie and Grace listen...
Teacher asked me why we raise Black  Angus-Herefords 'stead of Pure Herefords.
Tell her they suit the weather better.  Their udders are black, 'stead of pink.
They don't get burned by the sun bouncing  off the snow. And they're good mother.
Our daddy raised Pure Herefords. Silence... Eating... Annie tries her hand at conversation

You know, that's interesting. I always  wondered when I went into a restaurant  what was the difference between a regular  steak or a Black Angus steak. I couldn't  taste any difference although I could  swear one was more tender. I didn't know  there was that big a difference between  cows... (silence)
I've never been on a cow farm before. I  must say, the bulls seem to have the  best time of it. Just laying around the  fields all day until they're asked to... (uncomfortable)
do their... work.
Well, get born a bull, got a ninety  percent chance of getting castrated and  served up as hamburger. On a balance I  reckon I'd choose being a cow. (to Grace)
Would you mind passing that salad  young lady?
How's Peterson's holding up for you?
(lying)
It's fine. Comfortable. I still can't  get used to how dark it gets around here,  though. When we leave the ranch, I  always hold my breath until I can see  the motel.
(innocently)

You know, Tom, while you're working on  that horse of theirs, Annie and Grace  should move into the old Creek house. Diane and Tom react accordingly; Diane hiding her annoyan Tom hiding his surprise and pleasure.
Nobody's using it. Silly for her to be  driving back and forth when she don't  know her way around that well...
Oh, I don't know...
Well, I know Peterson's. Old place is as  good as falling down around your ears.
(overlapping)
They're already all settled in, Frank.  Anyway, I'm sure Annie wants her privacy.
It's got doors, Diane. Private as can be.  Tom?
I don't have a problem with that. It's up  to Annie.
Well, it's worth it, really? I mean, how  much longer do you think you need to work  with Pilgrim?
That's up to Pilgrim. Everyone waits on Annie's answer as she considers this.
Grace is on the phone with Robert. Annie is packing thing up. Grace is telling him about the day;
(listens)
I know. Me, too. Why don't you come  one weekend? Annie reacts to this.
We'll have more room because we're  moving onto the ranch. They have this  empty house near this creek. It's  actually pretty... OK... I love you. (to Annie)
Dad wants to talk to you.
(takes the phone)
Hi.
Robert is burning the midnight oil in the study with file all around him.
Hey... She sounds like she's doing  all right. How is she? Grace exits into the bathroom. Annie talks softly;
(cautious)

Yeah. She seems to be getting more  comfortable on the ranch, which is why  I said yes to this move. But, whenever  it's just the two of us, I don't know...  Anyway... what's happening with the  Delco lawsuit?
Taking forever. I just got an additional  list of sixty-two employees to interview  before Monday. I don't know how I'm going  to do it.
Well, it's good that you're there. Robert didn't mean to validate his separation from them.
So, how are you doing in Marlboro  country? Is the magazine complaining at  all?
Yeah, but nothing I can't handle. Lucy  tells me she thinks Gottchalks's  plotting, but what else is new.
When are you coming home?
You know, I just asked that myself  tonight. He doesn't know.
Well then... maybe I will take some  time... come visit.
Okay. Beat. Annie knows Robert needed an invitation from her. B she can't do it. Robert tries again.
I miss you, Annie.
I know. We miss you too.
Good night.
Night. Awkwardly, they hang up. Grace exits the bathroom.
Did you ask him to come visit?
You already did.
Did he mention it?
(resumes packing)
Yeah, he's going to think about it.  You want me to pack for you? Grace looks at her disapprovingly as she passes to go to bathroom. Annie registers this.

Diane is washing windows while listening to an audio book her tape player. Through the windows, she sees: Joe and the Twins helping Annie and Grace move into the C House. Diane has conflicting feelings about this. She continues work.

VARIOUS SHOTS of ANNIE CONNECTING HERSELF BACK TO THE RES THE WORLD, BY PLUGGING IN HER COMPUTER, FAX, ETC... Grace is in the other room, as she was in the motel. Alon With no television, she is just listening to her music la on the couch. The two women remain separate no matter whe they are. But we see a small difference. Grace rises and walks to t window. She looks out; POV: She sees people working about the ranch. Maybe Joe i among them -- riding his horse as he works. Or maybe it's just a vision of people with tasks to complete -- who do with pride, discipline and clarity. Grace looks out the window longingly.

A cloud of dust. A dozen or so horses are running in an a by the stables. Tom is riding among them, holding a long with an orange flag at the end of it, waving it at the yo horses, making them run away from him. The colts stay clo together. One of the horses, PILGRIM, stays at a distance to himself. Grace watches from along the railing. She alternates her  attention from the horses... to Tom.
What we're doing here, Grace, is  trying to get him to learn how to  be a horse again. He cracks the flag, the horses move together...
The others already know, see. That's  how they are in the wild -- herd  animals... (cracks the flag)

...When they've got a problem, like  they have now with me and this flag,  they look to each other. But old  Pilgrim there has forgotten. I'm the  rock and they're the hard place. He  thinks he hasn't got a friend in the  whole wild world... C.U. on GRACE, who clearly feels the same way... but want desperately not to. She watches him ride off towards Pilg who has stopped like all the others at the far end of the ring. He stands by himself, tossing his head, snorting, n wanting to be around other horses. Tom cracks the flag,  keeping them moving. Pilgrim does his own private dance. Tom rides by Grace and hands her the stick;
Hold this for a minute... Grace stiffens. She doesn't want to, but she's afraid to "No" to Tom. He just insists by tossing it to her...

Hold onto it, go on... She's forced to catch it. He turns and rides away, chasin down Pilgrim, trying to edge him toward the herd. For a  moment, he has him breaking to the left with the horses. as soon as he's clear of Tom, he separates himself and co to stop on his own. Tom rides back to Grace, taking back the flag.
We'll get there, Grace. As he says this, he flashes a small, reassuring smile and little wink. Grace melts just a little. As he rides away. Annie appears, having come from the Creek House. She call

Grace? The clinic just called...  They had to change your physical  therapy appointment. We have to  leave now. Grace frowns a little -- her mother's "perfect timing." A approaches the arena, watching Tom riding. As he passes h
Hello, Annie... Annie notices how he says her name.

Mr. Booker... He flashes a smile in her direction and Annie's expressio comically matches her daughter's reaction. She quickly co it, however. Her eyes follow him as he glides around the  arena. It's like watching a great ballet -- his control o horses, his effortlessness, his grace, his strength... Sh smiles to herself in appreciation. Then catches herself:
(to Grace)
You got everything you need?
If I had everything I need, I wouldn't  be going to physical therapy. Tom approaches as he overhears Grace respond;
(trying to cheer her)
Honey, come on. Would you like to stay  in town for dinner? Maybe see what  movie's playing tonight?
Why? There's no food in the house?
No. I just thought... forget it. He's getting a clearer view of their relationship.
You know, we're branding here  tomorrow. If you two want to come  by to watch or give a hand, you're  welcome.
(laughs)
Branding? (sarcastic)
I haven't branded in years. Tom chuckles.
I'll come.
Uh, I don't, honey. Branding? Oooh...  I think we'd just be in Mr. Booker's  way.
As long as you don't get in the way of  the branding iron, it doesn't matter too  much. Annie smiles. She turns to Grace, questioningly. Grace sa matter-of-factly, to prove her point.
I watched Margo Neuberger get a  tattoo. Tom squints. Annie shrugs and nods.
Okay. As Grace and Annie walk to the car, Tom says:

Hey, Grace -- maybe we can get your  mom to put me and you branding on the  cover of her magazine. Start a whole  new fashion craze. They continue walking as Grace smiles, enjoying being sin out for his joke. Annie responds, almost flirtatiously.

Try not to fall off your high horse,  Mr. Booker. Tom tips his hat and rides away... Annie smiles and nods. Grace doesn't like their sudden familiarity. Or her mothe coy manner. As they enter the Suburban, Grace asks point
Did you call Dad today? Annie is caught off guard. Tom, riding in the arena, catches himself looking after t then goes riding after Pilgrim.

The air smells of scorched flesh. There is nothing but NO Calves, separated from their mothers, "cry." They are mov out through a series of connected pens into a narrow chut and then one by one into a holding pen. They're clamped a lowered sideways onto a table and given a shot, a yellow  insect tag in one ear, branded, then sent back to their  mother's. The bulls, in a pen by themselves, stand haught paying no attention. Frank helps "doctor" the calves. Joe brands. Annie and Grace are standing by the railing, watching wit mixture of fascination and disgust. Tom moves in the feeder pen, waist deep in calves, moving through the chute. He looks to Annie.
Hey, over there, you want to make  yourself useful? It isn't a question.
Hank, I got you a volunteer! Annie and Grace realize they have no choice.

head_text.subj: -- WHAT FOLLOWS IS A SEQUENCE OF SCENES SHOWING ANNIE AND
GRACE PARTICIPATING IN THE BRANDING. AND HOW THEY GRADUAL
COME TO LOSE THEMSELVES IN THE EXPERIENCE.
-- HANK, A RANCH HEAD, HELPING ANNIE INTO THE CHUTE... AN
-- GRACE BEING SHOWN HOW TO HOLD THE BRANDING IRON.
-- HANK TEACHING ANNIE HOW TO SAY "HYAH
-- TOM IN THE HOLDING PEN WITH HIS ARMS AROUND GRACE, SHO
HER HOW TO APPLY THE BRAND... GRACE, A LITTLE FRIGHTENED
BRAND, IS IN HEAVEN IN TOM'S ARMS...
-- ANNIE IS STILL TRYING TO SAY "HYAH"
SHE CLAPS HER HANDS, PUSHING THE CALVES ALONG, KNEE DEEP

text: That's good... firm but gentle... (Grace opens her eyes)
It hurts but he'll get over it. Grace smiles proudly.

You handled that pretty well. Think  it's time you earn your keep around  here. So, when we're not working  and when you don't have your therapy,  I'd like you to help out with the  horses... Rubbing them, cleaning up  the stalls... You think you can  handle that? Grace knows him well enough to know;
That's not a question, is it?

You're catching on. Grace smiles. -- Annie turns and, not looking where she's doing, trips a calf, falling down. And calves, coming down the chute,  start to run towards her. Suddenly, Tom grabs her by the and pulls her to safety. He helps her up and dusts her of
(not wanting to smile,  but...)
You okay?
It is cocktail hour yet? Tom laughs. She takes a big breath.

The ranch is colored in amber light. Near the house, two long tables pushed together to make o long one... A gentle breeze ruffles the tablecloth. Every is seated for a meal. We hear laughter and conversation.. parachute into the middle of the moments; -- Hank helping with his wife get to their three children sit still for dinner... -- Diane organizing the women and their various plates of dishes... -- The Ranch Hand piling up their plates and kidding each other... -- Joe is instructing Grace on the various sauces for the ribs. The Twins are making fun of him behind his back. -- Tom and Smokey are barbecuing, the last one to sit. -- Frank assists his frail mother, ELLEN BOOKER, at the t filling her plate with all the things she can't reach for

The faces are beautiful. Laughing. Eating. Everyone is ta and exhausted after a long day, but filled with life and  eager to live it. The tables are covered with heavy food. The communion at this table is as much a part of the ritu as the branding itself... Annie and Grace look different to us. Tanned from the sun their bodies sore -- they feel softened, yet more vital. the artifice had been worn off... the armor of urban life the table thrives with conversations, we focus on: Annie and Ellen Booker. Annie looks calmer than we've see her -- and more naturally beautiful. She is seated beside Ellen Booker. We sense they have been talking for a while Annie is so sincerely interested in listening to her, she hardly touched her own plate...

... he was a blacksmith by trade, my  father. My grandson Joe was named  for him. But he always dreamed of  having his own place and raising  horses... We see Tom a few places down and across from Annie and hi mother -- but fully aware of their conversation.

He'd heard of some land. What's  Stockett now. Rode out there. Got off  his horse and walked about as far as  he could in one way. Then he walked as  far as he could another way and  another until he got back to where he  started and that's where he put his  roots down... That's where my husband  and I ranched and raised Frank and  Tommy... She motions proudly to Tom who looks up. Annie smiles to He looks to her with gratitude for the respect she's show his mother.
Quite a different life from what you  know, I expect. Which place to you  call home?
Well, I was born in London, but my  father was an ambassador and we  moved constantly. I've lived in a lot  of places but I don't really know what  I'd call home. Tom listens to this.
An ambassador! My! That's very  important.
He was a wonderful man. She looks to Tom and he can sense a sadness around this i eyes.
(to Grace)
I sure hope you're gonna eat more  than that, young lady. You're a  growing girl.
I've never eaten this much in my  life.
Probably never worked so hard,  neither. Those arms of yours are  gonna be pretty sore tomorrow. I'll  give you a little bit of ointment I  make. It's a magic recipe my Mama  gave me.
We used to call Diane's mother  Medicine Woman. None of us never went  to the doctor when she was alive. Annie and Grace listen in...
Too bad she wasn't here for old  Henry Vanoker...
Not much would have helped him.
I never got that whole story, what  happened?
Old Henry was changing a flat tire on  his truck over on 118 when that... (laughs)
... two-hundred-year-old jack he has  gives way and the side of that truck  come slamming down on that rock he  calls head... There's laughter -- everyone knows Old Henry. Except:
What happened?
Knocked him out for a while. He woke  up, finished putting on the tire and  drove himself to the hospital.

Old Fool... Darling, pass down those peas  for me, thank you. Annie and Grace don't know how to respond... But everyone takes it their stride as they continue eating... Grace notices Joe is whispering something to Frank, who n his head and speaks to the table.
Huh, Joe here has something to say. Joe stands, somewhat formally, with his hat on.

I wrote this for you Grandma... Mrs. Booker, and Diane, beam. Annie and Grace don't know to expect. Joe stands straight as an arrow and recites a from memory... At first, Annie and Grace appear to be embarrassed for th but soon they can't help but be won over by his guilessne He finishes and everyone applauds. Hank's wife asks:
That was lovely. Who wrote that,  Joe?
I wrote it myself, ma'am.
Now son, you tell 'em when it came  from.

Be honest, I can't say I did it all  myself. My grandma helped me get the  words right. OOoo's and aah's and smiles and conversations erupting ov each other. Only we see, Grace looking over to Joe who gives her kick shy grin...
(raising his beer)
Well, I'd like to welcome Annie and  Grace to their first branding...
And next time, Miss Annie, you can run  down the calves...

I'll drink to that... Everyone toasts and drinks. Annie and Tom exchange a look She smiles, but not in a alluring way -- rather, in a gra way. Grateful for this brief moment of community and good feeling. And somehow, Tom knows what she's feeling. No one notices this silent exchange -- except for Diane, sees everything that's going on.

The Women are bringing in dishes and plates and food from tables through the house and into the kitchen. Annie is a them, feeling apart of the group. She enters carrying a l bowl, that held the corn. Diane is replacing newly-cleaned forks and knives in her  dining room drawers, above which are several FAMILY PICTU
(referring to clean bowl)
Where does this go, Diane?
Oh, you can just set up on the dining  table. I have to rearrange my shelves  tomorrow. Annie complies. She notices the framed pictures on the wa the dining room.
Is this Mr. Booker? Tom's  grandfather? Diane looks at a faded photo circa late 1800's.
Mm-mm. I never knew him. He died  before Frank and I met. This here's... (another photo)
Frank and Tom's mother and father...  there's little Frank and Tom...
She calls him Tommy...

Always did. I think she favored him a  little. You tend to when you have more  than one, even though you love 'em all  the same. She studies the old faces of Tom's Parents -- although 20 Century people, there is still a pioneering strength in t visage... a stoicism and power.
(putting away forks)

Ha, she loves telling this story about  how when he was two years old, he ran off.  They found him in the barn, sleeping  between two giant hooves of a Percheron  stallion. She said that horse was  protecting him and nobody could convince  her otherwise.
I got a little confused though. The ranch  Ellen was talking about -- that's not this  one? Diane is sorting silverware throughout the following:

No. See, Frank and Tom were raised near  the Clark's Fork River, right between the  Pryor and Beartooth Mountains. Beautiful  piece of land. But they had this uncle  Ned -- useless man, never interested in  ranching. And when the grandparents died,  he left for the city and sent word  through lawyers he wanted his claim to  the land so he could sell it. Three years  of legation broke their father. Frank took  it all in stride, but Tom... Tom loved that  land. I don't think he ever got over it --  His home being sold out from under him.  Seeing his father like that. Once he and  Frank got their folks set up in a new  place, Tom left... went off. We didn't see  him for years... Annie is intrigued by what she's learning about Tom.  Something outside the window catches her eyes. She watche POV; Tom and Frank, on either side to Ellen, are escorting her a car that will drive her home.
Annie wanders out, passing Grace and Joe on her way out. are sitting in a glider. As Annie exits O.C., we hear the
Why do you always wear that hat?
Because it fits my head. You want to  try it on? Grace doesn't know if she should. Annie continues towards Tom who's sitting in a rocker pla with the twins.
Show us again! Come on! One more time!  It's my turn now!

All right, al right. Hold out your  finger. Annie takes a seat nearby and watches as Tom holds out th first finger of his right hand. The Twins holds out his. splits his focus between Annie and the Twins as he takes small piece of rope out of his back pocket. He ties the e together making a loop. He puts the loop over the Twin's  finger. And holding the other end of the loop taut with h left hand, he draws one side of the cord over the other w the middle finger of his right hand. Then he rolls his ha over so it's under the loop, and back over it again, so t his finger is tip to tip with the Twin's. The loop seemin knotted around their touching fingertips, and can only be removed if their touch is broken.
The loop's knotted, right. (Twins nod)
Looks like the only way to take it  off, is if we break our touch... (they nod)
Watch now... Annie and the Twins look down at the touching fingers as gently pulls the rope away, revealing they are still knot and without even breaking their touch...
Again! Again. One more time!
Oh, no. No, no. I only fall for that  once. Go inside now before your mother  starts hunting you down. Go on. The Twins exit. Annie and Tom make eye contact.
(smiles, relaxes back)
So how was your first and last day of  branding?
Don't be so sure it's my last. There  are a few people back home I'd like  to put under a red hot iron. Tom looks at her with a sly expression, and notices she's shivering.
You got too much sun today...  Here... He takes his jacket and puts it around her shoulders.
Thank you. He sits back down. Annie crosses her arms over her chest, looks around, unconsciously swinging her foot. Tom watche her leg. Annie notices him watching;
What?
You ever just stand still for a  minute?
You stand still too long in New York  you get hit by a bicycle messenger. (smiles wryly)
You know, sometimes, I get the feeling,  Mr. Booker, that you're laughing at me.  Why is that? Tom shrugs. Annie waits a beat, then:
That's your cue to say you're not  laughing at me.
Oh, I see, you write both sides of the  conversation?
It's a man's world, Mr. Booker. Most  women have to.
Well, maybe I am laughing a bit... I  just thought, as long as you're here,  it would be nice for you to relax into  the place a little.
(understanding)
Well... It's beautiful country, I'll give  you that. And I could see having some  kind of vacation place. Retreat. But I  don't know how you do it full time. Don't  you miss the rest of the world?
What's that to miss?
Ha... if you've never lived in a city  with museums, theater, music, restaurants,  uh... god, a million things, then it's  something I can't explain.
(thinks, teasing a bit)
Does Chicago count?
(surprised)
You lived in Chicago?
When I was first married.
(stunned)
You were married to a woman in  Chicago? Tom likes disturbing her picture of him as the predictabl cowboy. He smiles;

I once heard Itzhak Perlman guest star  with the Chicago Symphony Orchestra.  He played Rachmaninov's Vocalize Opus 34.  No. 14. It was one of the most beautiful  pieces of music I ever heard. I actually  forgot where I was for a time. (Annie is floored)
You seem surprised?
(not wanting to insult)
Well, I, uh... you didn't...

Just who's been laughing at who here? Tom says this with a wry smile. Annie returns with a smil as an understanding is reached between them: they've both stereotyped the other. They are both pleased -- and attra by what they don't know.
Grace is fast asleep, exhausted. She does not stir when t phone rings. Annie picks up from her own bed, awakened, still dressed her branding clothes, having just passed out on the bed.
Hello?
INTERCUT: Robert, alone, in the vast apartment.
I thought you guys were going to call  me.
Oh, Robert, I'm sorry. We were so tired  from the branding. Grace barely made it  to her bed and I didn't have the energy  to take my clothes off.
Oh well... branding will do that to you.
Everything all right.
Huh-huh. You?
Fine. Actually, today was a good day.  You should have seen her.
I wish I did. The sound of self-pity was so obvious for both of them, s Robert quickly re-groups, resorting to something he knows important to her;
Well, uh the real reason I called,  actually, was to tell you I saw Lucy  at Jo-Jo's tonight and she seems very  worried.
About what?

Apparently, Gottschalk's been seen around  town lunching with some very prominent  magazine editors. Lucy said she tried to  call you, but no one answered so she faxed  you the list of names. She said one of  them have contracts up fairly soon.
Oh. I didn't look at my faxes today. We  left before sunrise.

Honey, I hope you're not endangering  your position. Listen, if you need to  come back and you want me to come take  over, for a while, I'll work it out. I  mean, the firm's got other lawyers, but  the magazine's got only one of you. After a day of hard work and simple pleasures, Annie begi succumb to old anxieties and pressures.

Annie is awake reading the faxes Lucy sent. One after oth As she flips through them, one falls to the floor near th She gets down on all fours to retrieve and sees something under the bed. AN OLD, BATTERED CELLO CASE. She pulls it to find the initials R.B. carved on the top. She opens it find papers, receipts, bills -- all from Tom's married li

Tom rides a young colt along the creek. He hears footstep He turns and sees Annie running along the creek on the ot side. He stops to watch. When his horse SNORTS, Annie loo up to see him. She stops. He tips his hat to her.
I've decided it's impossible to  properly say hello in this place  without a hat.
A jogger, huh?
I don't jog, Mr. Booker. I run.
Lucky for you. The grizzlies around  here only go for joggers.
If I can survive rush hour, I figure I  can handle grizzlies...
(smiles)
You sleeping all right in that house?
I don't sleep all right anywhere. But  the house is fine. Tom walks his horse across the creek to her, comfortable the silence. Annie moves about, uncomfortable in the wait
Who's R.B.? Tom is finding Annie's blunt curiosity more endearing.
I found this old cello case filled with  bills and receipts.
Sorry about that. I thought everything  got cleared out. R.B. is my wife...  ex-wife... Rachel. We used to live in  that house  together.
I thought you lived in Chicago?

I thought you were an editor, not a  reporter? Annie smiles and nods, realizing she's asking too many qu She tries to casually reach out to touch the horse's head it's too abrupt and the horse tosses his head away, takin couple of steps back. Annie is embarrassed.
I have a way with animals.
It's all right. He's young. Just hold  out your hand a little lower so he can  get the smell of you.
Oh yes. I forgot. She does and the horse sniffs at her hand.
He's beautiful.
Why don't you ride anymore? Grace told  me you used to ride when she was  younger.
She did? Annie is somewhat moved by her daughter telling him that.
I don't know, really. No time mostly. A cold wind blows. She folds her arms across her breasts.
I thought it was supposed to be spring. Tom can't help but notice her nipples are hard from the c He looks away. She laughs.
Are you shy, Mr. Booker?
Just polite. Well, maybe you'd like  to try riding again, some time before  you go home. Annie is struck by the words "before you go home." Tom am off on his horse.
Enjoy the day.
You too. Annie steps across the rocks at the ford, crossing the cr Her foot slips, one of her shoes goes into the water.
Shit.
Need a lift?
I can handle it! She crosses the creek. She turns, giving him a small wave touches his hat. She runs off. Tom watches her go, head d concentrating...
A tense Annie is having a difficult phone with DAVID GOTT
... David, we've been behind a day or  two before. But Lucy just Fedexed me all  the material and it'll be approved by  the end of the day.

If nothing goes wrong. If the faxes don't  go down. If the phone lines are opened.  I can't have this magazine hitting the  streets by the skin of its ass, Annie. During David's lines, Diane has entered, carrying fresh t -- she crosses into the bathroom.
Oh, come on! This is such bullshit! The  work is getting done, David. Lucky keeps  me on top of everything.

Lucy isn't you. We're losing something  without you being here. Now, I know this  is a rough time for you, but I think we  should make another arrangement. Without Annie's awareness, Diane re-enters and takes her leaving, so she can take in all of Annie's things; her  business "office," books, etc...
What the hell does that mean? How much  more do I have to do to prove how  important this magazine is to me?
If this magazine is so important to you  Annie, why are you in Montana? Diane can't help but notice a slight vulnerability in Ann

Look, this is what we're going to do.  Finish up this issue. I'll set up a  conference call in a few weeks. Just  you, me and your lawyer and we'll  just work this out so that everyone  will be taken care of. Fair enough? Annie is now aware of Diane's presence and chooses to pla cool. It's not the moment.
Uh, yes... Sure, David.
All right. Speak to you then. He hangs up. Annie forces a smile to Diane.
Thank you. You're all doing too much.

Oh, it's... I wanted to tell you that,  if you'd like, you being so busy, I  could take Grace to her therapy  exercises for you. I have to go in  once a week for shopping anyway. Annie doesn't know whether or not to accept.
Oh... Well... thank you very much. I  don't -- Before she finishes her line, the Phone Rings again.
Sorry. (to phone)

Hello? Hi, yeah, I just spoke to him.  Oh, you know David, Mr. Strong Arm... Diane feels out of place and exits. Annie doesn't notice  until she hears the door close. She pushes back her hair takes a deep breath. She looks out through the side windo and sees: Grace and Joe doing chores. Grace looks involved and not all self-conscious. A moment of gratitude and calm for An

Pilgrim bursts out of a chute and into the riding arena. runs to the far end and abruptly stops. Tom is holding th orange flagstick, and coiled rope, coming through a gate  into the arena, crossing to the middle of the ring. Somet in his demeanor tells us that fun and game are over. Pilgrim and Tom stand there, motionless, eyeing each othe Pilgrim snorts and takes a few, small steps backward. Tom takes a beat, then starts slowly towards Pilgrim, lifting flag and "cracking" it. At the sound, Pilgrim whirls away him and runs, around the arena. He starts to slow, lookin Tom. Again, Tom cracks the flag and Pilgrim runs, round a round the arena... like a ringmaster, Tom keeps Pilgrim  moving, cracking the flag. Something about Tom's demeanor tells us it isn't going we

Tom, carrying a saddle, comes around the side of the barn Through the slats, he sees Grace working in the barn,  watering a horse. She has stopped and is looking through cracks of Pilgrim's stall at him. She turns and sees Tom  through the slats. She goes back to work as Tom comes to barn door.
Come and take a ride with me.
They walk towards his pick-up truck.
Can you drive?
Drive? I'm not old enough yet.
It's never too soon to start. He enters the passenger side.
I can't...
I don't have all day. She hesitates and gets into the truck.
Grace doesn't know what to do.
Put the key in and turn it. (Grace obeys)
The right pedal is gas, the other  one's the brake.
I don't know if I can with my leg.
Well, there's only one way to find out. (puts truck in gear)
Give it a little gas. She awkwardly puts her prosthetic foot on the gas pedal. much. It lurches forward. She takes her foot off.
Well, we know you can. Now you just  got to feel how much. Try it again. She does. They slowly, very slowly, move along the dirt r
Nice, real nice. There's a little  road down at the end here, turn onto  it. Grace badly oversteers, but makes the turn. She drives al the road, across a pasture, heading toward distant mounta
Just follow this. Nothing to it. I'm  going to shut my eyes here for a  little while. Just keep going till  you run out of road.
(afraid)
I don't know if I can.

Not a question of if you can -- you  are. Just keep your eyes on the road  and your foot on the pedal and the  rest will take care of yourself. Folding his arms over his chest, shutting his eyes, Tom  relaxes back. Grace locks her hand on the steering wheel her eyes straight ahead...
The truck is parked at the foot of a mountain. Grace, ver pleased with herself, sits beside Tom on the cab's roof,  looking around them at the great Montana. After a beat;
Where did you get Pilgrim from?
We bought him in Kentucky. My mother  and I took a trip down there to see  him.

That must have been pretty special. Grace nods. It is a pleasant memory. He motions for her t quiet. An old ELK with a prodigious rack of antlers, has down out of the mountains. Seeing them, he stops in his  tracks, dead still. They watch each other. Then the elk t and runs back up into the mountains. Tom smiles at Grace smiles back -- partly because of the elk, partly because alone with Tom.
Are you afraid of anything?
(thinks)
Getting old. Not being of much use,  I guess. (beat)
What went on out there, Grace? With  Pilgrim? Grace doesn't say anything. Tom nods then;

You see, Grace, I've got a problem.  When I'm working with a horse, I like  to know its history. Now, most times,  the horse can tell you pretty much the  whole story, but sometimes he can be  so messed up in his head that you need  more to go on. You need to know exactly  what went wrong. Often times, it's the  obvious thing, but something that went  wrong just before that, maybe even some  little thing... Grace is quiet. She doesn't want to think about that.

It's like if I'm driving and run into  a tree. When somebody asks me, "Well,  what happened?", I don't say, "Well,  I plowed into a tree." I'd say, "The  sun was in my eyes." or "I skidded." or  "I took my mind off the road for a  second." See what I mean? (Grace nods)

I don't know how you feel about talking  about it and I can understand you might  not want to. But if I'm going to figure  out what's going on in his head, it'd  sure help if I knew exactly what  happened that day. Grace looks away. Tom smiles and gently puts his arm arou her shoulders, which has a soothing effect on Grace -- ma her feel safe...
Not today -- whenever you feel like it.  I leave it up to you. Grace looks into Tom's eyes, wanting so much to unburden to him and have him make everything all right. She nods.

Tom is making his way to the house at the end of the day, he stops and looks over to the Creek house -- POV -- the lights are on. And he can see Annie, exhausted approving pages, talking on the phone and faxing all  simultaneously. He gets an idea.

Annie sits on the porch of the creek house, with a guilt herself, sipping coffee and deep in thought. She looks up see: Tom riding towards the house on his horse, leading anothe horse behind him. He looks to her and smiles.
(murmurs)
Oh-oh. Tom reaches the house as Annie rises.
The answer's no.
You haven't heard the question yet. Truth  is, you'd be doing me a favor. I got all  these eager young colts need riding and  poor old Rimrock here is feeling kind of  left out...
Poor thing.
He'd be grateful, he'd take real good  care with you.
Is this how you're going to make me pay  my phone bill?
No, ma'am, I'm afraid that's extra. She gives him a crooked smile.
Annie, in Levis and a jacket, rides Rimrock beside Tom ac the pasture. We overhear them in the midst of talking.
Relax our center... It's just sitting  in a bucket.
Yeah, it's been a while, but I... I  remember the basic ideas...
OK. I'll stop talking then. He rides a few steps ahead as Annie realizes she doesn't  remember. She just went into automatic "I don't have to b told anything" mode.
Actually, I never rode Western. I'm  sorry. Go ahead.
Well, he don't know that. Just sit the  horse. (watches her ride)
Good... You have a nice seat.
Thanks.
Feel good?
Yeah.
You look all right. You want to pick  it up a little?
Tom urges his horse into a center. Annie canters alongsid

Watch your reins, he'll go with you,  give him some room, let him do the  work. Relax, don't grab him with  your thighs, just so long as he can  feel your body. Annie responds to every suggestion without resistance. An she experiences this sense of pleasure -- this great anim beneath her, the physicality and the surrender of letting someone else lead...

You want to let it go some more? She begins to let herself go, losing herself in the exper She just nods... Tom breaks into a full gallop... Annie f suit... She lets everything go -- her job, her marriage,  motherhood, guilt, anxiety... all of it. Her only focus i horse beneath her, and the man on the horse leading her..
They ride along the creek, crossing at a ford. They ride towards the mountains.
They ride through a narrow pass with sheer rock walls, ri by a waterfall...
They ride across a meadow, cattle stepping lazily aside t let them pass. And as they ride alongside each other,  appreciating the silence...

They ride up along a sloping ridge covered with pine tree They come to the rim of a high bluff. They stop. They loo out at the twin valleys that gave the ranch its name. And they can just see the old CREEK HOUSE hidden in the shade some trees along the creek... Tom looks over at Annie, who is looking out over this  beautiful vista.

It's a whole other world you have  going on here. It just goes along,  doing what it has to. And you're a  part of it, you just wake up and,  and there you are... And everything  that seems like life or death some  place else -- doesn't affect any of  this one bit. Tom is impressed by her feelings. He sees her saddle cinc needs fixing and gets off his horse.
Lift your leg. Annie complies once she realizes what he's doing.
How long did you live here with your  wife?
Five years. My son was born here.
(opens her eyes)
Son?

Yeah. I haven't seen him in a while. He  used to come to the ranch over summers,  but then he started having friends and  was going off to college, so... Good boy.  Hal. Lives in New York near his mom.
How did you meet her?

College. In Illinois. She was playing  the cello. I hadn't heard cello music  growing up. She had the reddest hair,  the bluest eyes. When she played, it  was... Tom can't find a beautiful enough word. But Annie underst
She was the most beautiful thing I'd  ever seen. Annie sees Tom as if with new eyes -- his love for this w he lost.
Why didn't it work out?

She was never really happy here. She did  the best she could. Annie looks at him and for the first time senses a kinshi an understanding they both have of being torn between two worlds... a desire for home...
Grace told me you have a country house  in Connecticut. Sounds like a beautiful  place.
It is. It's lovely.
Ever think of moving there full time?

We did at one point. When we thought  we'd have more children. And we after  tried. We tried everything, but...  wasn't meant to be. There is an awkward silent beat for a moment. Annie is  momentarily self-conscious. Tom helps by speaking of hims

I hear that! See, I knew she was never  going to be a ranchest, but I wanted  to try -- I thought maybe she'd give  music lessons to the kids in town or at  the school, maybe even recitals. My son  would grow up here. Maybe have one or  two more. I'd teach 'em what I could.  They'd play with my brother's kids. All  grow up together. And even if they all  decided to go out into the world, they'd  always know where home was -- cause we'd  keep it for 'em...
That's very important to you, isn't it?  Home.

Yeah, I think it is. And I don't mean  everybody's got to be married, have kids -- It's more like, knowing where you're  from, where you belong, what feeds you,  where you can go no matter what happens...  Knowing what you're supposed to be doing  while you're here.
How did you find out all that? Tom looks right into her eyes and confesses without a shr of self-consciousness.
I got lost. They smiles.

The world is in silhouette. Off in the distance, we see T standing by his horse, offering his hand to Annie, helpin her off. There's an awkward moment, neither of them wanti the day, or the moment, to end.
Grace is standing by the window, looking out at them. The movements indicate an intimacy that upsets her.
After a beat; Tom gets back on his colt. He takes Rimrock's reins and l him off. Annie stops for a moment, watching him ride away She watches her mother walk towards the house;

Grace watches her mother stand there a moment, then turn walk towards the house. Grace moves away from the window, her emotions churning -- jealousy, anger -- and enters he bedroom, shutting the door.
Joe, hat tipped low, is riding his horse, leading some yo horses, exercising them in the morning pasture. He sees G walking with her cane, coming across the pasture.
(shy)
Hi... She stops. After a beat;
Would you let me ride your horse?
(hesitates)
Have you talked to Tom about it?
Of course I have.
(beat, then:)
I don't know... You sure Tom said it's  all right? She nods. He hesitates.

Are you going to give me a hand or  aren't you? He gets off his horse and holds it. She puts down her can then puts her hand on the saddle horn. She puts her  prosthetic leg into a stirrup. Frightened, she starts to  shake;

You sure? Angry, determined, Grace tries to swing her leg onto the  horse. She can't do it. Tears of frustration on her face. tries again. She manages to pull herself halfway on, her  prosthetic leg buckles and she falls. Frightened, Joe run her.

You okay? She gasps to catch her breath. He reaches to help her up. pulls her hand away. Embarrassed, she "runs" off. Joe rem still. He hears a little VOICES. He turns and sees the TW having been watching the whole thing from a small hill. A they run off, he yells, threateningly.
You better not say anything!!!
We follow Joe running towards the creek house, fastening good shirt. He's dressed and cleaned for dinner. He's lat

Annie is in the midst of making a spaghetti dinner. She's little frazzled but she's on top of it. Grace enters wear a lovely dress -- it is the first time we have seen her i dress. Annie hears her enter before she sees her, asking;
Honey, would you see if anybody  wants -- Annie notices Grace standing there, in her dress. She sto
You look really pretty. Grace is a little self-conscious but grateful. She begins taking forks out of her dress pocket.
I thought there were too many forks  on the table.
Well, one was for salad...
Mom, they don't mind eating with one  fork.
(thinks, then;)
You're right. Good. Grace puts them away.
Does anybody out there want  something to drink?
I'll take care of it.
Thanks, honey. Grace nods and exits to the living room.

The room is silent because every Booker is READING A  DIFFERENT COPY OF ANNIE'S MAGAZINE. Frank covertly glimps at the scantily-clad models... The Twins sharing a magazi doing the same thing as their father, but keeping an eye for mom... Diane is looking at pictorial exposes on the k of lives she only hears about on audio tapes... Tom sits off to the side, amused by the sight. Grace enters as Joe enters. They nod across the room to e other with a little smile.
Would anyone like something to drink? We hear a CRASH in the kitchen, then:
Everybody looks up for a minute. The Twins giggle. Diane them a dirty look.
I'll give your mom a hand. Diane watches him enter the kitchen, then returns to her  magazine.
Annie has dropped a hot pot into the sink, after pouring tomato out of it, and into a terrine.
Everything under control?
(laughs)
Not really. I'd forgotten how long  it's been since I've done this. And  I couldn't get any Parmesan cheese.
Just make yourself comfortable.
I am comfortable.

Ha, ha... all right, well, uh I guess  you can bring out the pasta. She undoes her apron and crosses towards the bowl. Tom's never leave her. It's the first time he's seen her in her dress, sans apron. As she lifts the bowl to hand to him, realizes he's been looking at her. There's a silent momen then;
You missed a button.
Huh? She looks for it. Tom crosses to her and buttons it, then takes the bowl.
Thank you. They're quiet for a beat as they exchange a look. Suddenl Grace enters -- she clearly doesn't like the two of them alone, Annie quickly covers;
Oh, good, Grace, would you bring in  the bread... I'll get the salad and  then we're all set. Tom has already exited by the time Annie finishes, and Gr grabs the bread basket.
We parachute into the middle of the meal. The spaghetti i hit... We cut to different conversations and reactions ar the table. Frank is in the middle of saying;
It'd be a whole lot easier to pay  the feed end of the month...
I don't think Warren would go for that. Grace is talking to Joe and the Twins.

... like, for instance, you can go on  the Internet and access this thing  called The Visible Man -- who was this  murderer they caught in Texas that was  executed and donated his body to  science and you can call him up on the  screen and dissect him, like in Three-D... Grace eats as she talks. Joe and the Twins are fascinated Annie asks Tom, Frank and Diane;
Well, did you ever think about hiring  a business manager?
We have a business manager. The best  around.
Ha...
Diane takes care of the books. I don't  know how, but at the end of every  month, everything adds up to the penny.
Ain't brain surgery.
It's pretty impressive. Where I come  from, you'd be a gold mine. Diane doesn't know how to accept that, but inside she's  bursting with pride. She focuses on the Twins who fight;
This is MY fork. That's YOUR fork, ya  idiot!
Hey. You stop that kind of talk at the  table.
I'll have another round of that  spaghetti if may?
Absolutely. I made enough for an army.
I uh... I like the sauce very much. Maybe  I get the recipe. Annie is so pleased and is about to reply, but Grace, not Tom smiling at Annie:
It's from a jar. There's an odd silence as a deflated Annie serves Frank.
Thank you. Finally, Diane saves it.
Well, I tried jar sauce once --  wasn't this good. Ya gotta know  which brand to buy. I'd like to  get the name of this one. Annie is grateful. Grace feels foolish.
Can we see the dead body on the  screen?
What?
It's just my computer.
Oh, I don't --
It's okay. Grace, show them. I'm going  to put the coffee on. I made an apple  tart for dessert. The Twins excitedly move to the computer. Joe waits for G
I'll help you with the coffee.
Well... I know I should reject that  offer, but I'm not going to.
(jovial)

No reason you should, no reason you  should. They exit into the kitchen. Frank continues eating. Tom looks around -- Grace showing the boys the computer. and Diane in the kitchen. For a second, we see Tom realiz image of the life he once thought he could.
As Diane and Annie prepare coffee and dessert;
I was looking in one of your magazines  and saw that picture of the couple  getting married at the Pyramids. Were  you ever in Egypt?
I was there for that shot, actually.
What was it like?

Oh, God -- I think it was the fourth  or fifth time I'd been there, so all  I remember was the heat and how  incompetent the photographer was... She laughs as she directs this last line to Diane, who ju smiles. And Annie realizes that's not what she meant at a This woman is starving for glimpses into this other life.
But, uh, Egypt is, well, it's like  nothing else. It's like going back in  time. (Diane listens)

I remember as a kid trying to imagine  what a kid my age, centuries ago,  walking over that same ground, was  wondering about or, if they had the  same problems as me... and I felt,  connected to... to time itself, almost.  Ha, I never realized how hard it was  to describe.
I'd love to go there one time...
You and Frank ever take a vacation?

Soon. We're going to Branson, Missouri  to see my cousin Emma married. Frank  loves in there. Annie can sense the disappointment in her voice, and at t same time, the comfortable resignation. Suddenly, from inside, they hear LOUD OVERLAPPING VOICES the children fight.

head_text.subj: YA JUST HAD A TURN. IT WAS NOT.

text: Diane and Annie enter to find Joe and Scott fighting, as tries to break them up...
Boys! Settle down!
You never let me have a turn!
Don't be such a baby!
You just showing off for her!
You shut up, stupid!
You're the one who's stupid -- letting  her go and fall off your horse!! Everyone goes quiet, except for the computer screen.
You little shit!
I saw 'em. In the pasture. Her trying to  get on Gonzo! I saw 'em.
What does he mean?
Nothing.
Did you go riding?
Little shit! Joe lunges for Scott and the two start rolling in a fight Frank and Tom work to pull them apart as Diane yells.
Annie, I'm so sorry, but they're just  tired. We'll have dessert another time.  Frank, get them out of here. (to other Twin)

Come on. Say good night and thank  you... Voices everywhere. Yelling. "Thank you's!!" During which, Grace quickly turns and exits. Annie eyes follow her out the room, but with her guests and the chaos, she doesn't whether or not to leave.
Dinner was delicious. Thank you. (to Twins)
Say thank you!! Diane and Frank usher the kids out. Tom holds onto Joe un they're gone, then lets him go.
Sorry, ma'am, I thank you for dinner.  It was very good.
Did Grace try to ride, Joe?
(hesitates)
I expect you should talk to Grace about  that, ma'am. And if I did anything  wrong, then I am sorry. Ever the gentlemen, Joe exits. Annie looks to Tom. He's a to leave, when he stops and says:

Don't let her turn you away. Tom exits. Annie stands and faces Grace's closed door. Slowly, she  lowers herself to her knees and sits on them, thinking... reminiscent of Tom, waiting for his moment with Pilgrim, the field.
We don't know how long Annie waited, but she knocks gentl then enters to find Grace, in her nightgown, on her bed, the night stand light on. Her prosthesis is against the w
Grace? Is everything all right? (no answer)
Can we talk?
About what?
Well... (nervous)
So you tried riding again?
(snotty)
Yeah. Does that mean I'm cured?!
Honey, nobody's trying to cure you --
... You worried everything all right  now and we'll have to go home?
What are you talking about?
You... not wanting to go home because  you hate daddy so much.
Grace, I don't hate your father.
I can't remember the last time you  made him dinner.
I was just trying to say thank you to  Diane and Frank and --
Tom? Annie sits by the bed, Grace moves away a little.
Look, I just wanted to say, I think  it's great you're riding again.  And... and I think I know why you,  you needed to do it alone... without  anyone knowing...
Yeah, you know everything!!
STOP IT! Why can't I talk to you!!
NO, YOU STOP IT! Stop pretending like  you care! Like this really isn't about  you and Tom.
(angry)
WHAT?! How can you -- (at a loss)

I'm sorry if my friendship with Tom  bothers you so much, but I happen to  value having someone to talk to,  especially when my own daughter  ignores me night and day because no  matter what I say, it's wrong and no  matter what I do, it's wrong... I'm  sorry I'm such a disappointment to  you.
Well, now you know what it feels like. Beat.
I don't deserve that. I have never  looked at you as a disappointment. If  I'm on your back to do better, if I  push you to try harder it's because  I want you to be the best you can be.

FOR YOU! Because I'm your daughter  which means you're the best mother!  Isn't that what you're always talking  about in interviews -- having it all,  the great career, the great family...  Proving everybody wrong. Wanting  everybody to think you're this perfect  woman! Beat. They're both exhausted.

Listen, if... if there's a part of you  as parent that... that takes pride in  your child -- that, you can look at  them and see something you've  accomplished as well... if that's wrong,  then I'm sorry. (no answer)
But it wasn't my intention. I don't push  for me. I do it for you... So you don't  waste half your life feeling like you  don't know where you belong.
Yeah, well, you've done a great job. Beat. Annie feels deeply hurt.

Well, then I do apologize... But what  I'm most sorry for is turning you  into a spoiled brat who can only  think about what she's feeling... who  can't admit when she's wrong and who  can't forgive when she's not.
Annie stops to exit as Grace says something under her bre Annie stops.
What did you say?
I said... I started. Grace starts to sob. Annie doesn't understand.
Started what?
My period.
(softer)
When? Tonight?
(nods)

I felt it happen downstairs and when  I went into the bathroom. Annie reaches down to touch Grace's shoulder. Grace turns there is no anger in her face. Annie sits and takes her i her arms. Grace clings to her and sobs like a little girl Annie sees tears run -- gratefully, lovingly.
Who's going to want me now?
What?... Oh baby...
Who's ever going to want me? Nobody  will.
That's not true.
Why should they?
Because you are... one of the most...  incredible, bravest, most beautiful  woman I have ever met. The efforts  you make. Your courage and your  dignity. (laughs thru tears)

I don't know where you got it? I  honestly don't know how I would have  handled all this if I were you. Grace is so grateful, they cling to each other even harde As the tears subside, Grace manages to admit...

I'm sorry... about what I said. It's  just that -- all those times you  and Daddy were trying for another  kid, I... I used to pray at night that  it would work. And not because of  you guys or that I wanted a brother  or sister... but... just so I wouldn't  have to be...
What?

So special. Because I was the only  one. You both wanted me to be so  good at everything, so perfect and  I wasn't. I was just me. And now I've  completely ruined everything,  anyway... They both start crying again as Annie rocks her gently.
Sshhh... Ssshhhh... They hold each other as if for dear life... LATER -- CAMERA PANS to discover mother and daughter, fas asleep, in each other's arms.

Tom sits alone, writing at his desk. His music is playing He stops to look out the window overlooking the Creek Hou Annie and Grace fell asleep with the lights still on in t living room. Tom is thinking of Grace and Annie -- wondering what happ after he left... conflicted by what he feels for Annie... remembering why they're here in the first place...
The phone rings, awakening Annie first, then Grace.
Hello?
Hello, this is ATT Conference Service.  Is this Annie MacLean?
Yes.
I have a conference call scheduled for  you with Mr. Gottschalk and Mr. Farlow.
(remembering)
Oh. Oh, yes. One moment, please.
Who is it?
Uh, nothing. I'm going to pick it up  in the other room -- would you hang  this up for me?
Sure. Annie moves to the other room, sits down at her office sp takes a breath, then picks up, yelling to Grace;
Okay, Grace... (click)
Operator?... I'm ready.

Annie and Grace are standing by the arena fence. Frank, J and the Twins are sitting on the fence rail. Joe is holdi saddle and a bridle, standing in some shadows in an empty arena. Pilgrim comes running into the ring. Out of habit, starts circling the ring. He sees Tom holding a saddle.  Pilgrim walks towards him. Curious, he stops, looking at Tom puts the saddle down, sitting crossways on it. Pilgri walks towards him again. He stops, looking at Tom again. just sits there, playing with the bridle. Pilgrim walks  around him. Tom doesn't show him any interest. Pilgrim co closer. He looks at the saddle. He runs off. He stops,  looking back. Tom just sits. Pilgrim walks back over. Tom stands and shows him the bridle. Pilgrim comes closer,  sniffing it. He rubs his nose against the leather. Tom pa his head. Then, in one quick, but deft motion, he puts th bridle on him. Pilgrim tosses his head, but it doesn't se to bother him. Grace and Annie watch intently. Tom takes reins, walking Pilgrim around the ring. He walks him to t saddle. Pilgrim paws at it with his hoof. He turns and ru off. Tom lets him go. Pilgrim runs around the ring, slows down, looks over at Tom. Tom picks up the saddle. Pilgrim cautiously, comes back over. Tom, with the saddle, walks from him. Pilgrim, again curious, follows him. He nudges Tom stops. Pilgrim comes around to take a good look at th saddle. Tom rubs his back. And gently, like laying down a sheet, puts the saddle on his back. Pilgrim shuffles slig at the touch. Tom quickly cinches it. Taking up the reins walks Pilgrim around the ring again. He starts to jog.  Pilgrim jogs with him. And in the middle of the jog, Tom  grabs onto the saddle horn, and without breaking his stri pulls himself back up onto his back. He lays across the  saddle, letting Pilgrim feel his weight. He sits up, and  without letting him break his stride, he urges Pilgrim wi his thighs, keeping him in the jog, riding around the rin Grace and Annie cheer. Tom tips his hat to them...

Grace is cleaning stalls, etc... She exits one of the sta with a pail and stops -- looking down the barn to where s knows Pilgrim is. She places the pail down and gathers he courage. She walks to Pilgrim's stall. She stands motionl for some moments before she opens the doors and enters... Pilgrim steps back a bit. He looks at her. He pins his ea back. Stomps his feet. Grace is about to turn and leave, she stops herself and remains still. Slowly, she reaches out to touch Pilgrim's head... and he lets her. We see in Grace a maturity of character, a  willingness to face what she must face... the beginning o compassion, not only for Pilgrim, but perhaps for herself well.

A full moon lights the ranch. Tom pulls up to the ranch h in his truck, parks and gets out. As he walks towards the house, he hears: Grace exits the Creek House and coming towards him, a coa over her nightgown. Tom waits until she reaches him.
I was waiting for you to come back. Tom instinctively knows what she wants.
You hungry?
Grace sits at the table. Tom is cooking at the stove. It as if they are the only two people on earth. Grace gets u nerve... and begins:
Judith was telling me about this boy  she really liked. She never even had  a chance to tell me his name... She starts to quietly cry, but it doesn't stop her.

We were going to go around by the  railroad bridge... And we see the accident all over again... But this time, movie -- as clear as reality -- but in deathly silence. J the sound of Grace's voice, and her heartbeat...
The horses are going up the icy path...

We were laughing about something, I  don't remember what. Her horse fell... Judith's horse suddenly stumbles on the ice, going down,  throwing Judith, her foot helplessly caught in the stirru Her horse sliding back down the hill. Grace tries to move Pilgrim to avoid the errant horse, bu it's too late, the horse plows into them, the horses slid back down the hillside onto the empty COUNTRY ROAD...
Pilgrim is first to find his legs. Judith's horse, its le broken at the ankle, walks in a confused state. Judith's is helplessly caught in the stirrup...
... Judith's foot was caught in the  stirrup... she couldn't get up, she  was so scared... (cries)
I saw this truck, coming around the  turn... She sees the glint of the steel. The Truck suddenly appea from around the bend.
...He was honking, trying to get us to  move... I tried to grab the reins to  get Judith's horse out of the way... Grace grabs the reins of Judith's horse. The horses are  spooking...
...And the truck started skidding... The truck skidded on the icy road, going out of control, knifing, heading right for them...
...It was coming right at us... There  wasn't any time to do anything... It  ran right into Judith's horse... The truck bed plows into Judith's horse...
...Judith just disappeared... And it  came right at Pilgrim and me... We see this...
...And Pilgrim reared up at the truck  and I fell off... Grace falls onto the road, the truck running over her.
Grace sobs uncontrollably now.
Judith... Oh God, Judith. I'm sorry... Tom is near and holds her as she puts her head on his che

I won't tell you it'll stop feeling  this bad... But I can tell you, you  didn't do anything wrong... The same  thing would have happened to me... or  Frank... or Joe... And there's no  sense in looking for a reason why  things happen... (self-reflective)

I used to try and... always came up  short. I don't think the why so's  important as... what we do with what  we get. I remember this boy I'd see  up on the Blackfeet Reservation. He  was sixteen. Great kid. Strong. He'd  gone swimming and dived headfirst into  a rock. Snapped his neck, paralyzed  him... After the accident, I'd look  in on him from time to time... and he  wasn't there anymore. His mind, his  spirit, whatever you want to call it,  it just disappeared. And what was left  was nothing but anger... It's like the  boy I knew just went away somewhere...
I know where he goes.
I know you do. Don't you disappear. (holds her tighter)
You do whatever you have to, to hold  on... (thinks)

I'll tell you one more thing... When  Pilgrim reared up to face that  truck... you know what I think?... I  think that damn horse loved you so much,  he was trying to protect you... That's  what I think. Grace listens to this. As Tom holds her in silence, it's  almost as if they were father and daughter...
Tom stands with Grace in the corral. Tom's horse, Rimrock saddled nearby. Tom takes Grace's cane.
Let me hold that... Grace stands, looking at the horse...
I can't... not yet...

There's no hurry. Take you time. She's trying so hard to be brave. After a moment, she rea for the saddle horn. She puts her prosthetic leg in the  stirrup, takes a breath and swings her leg up -- slipping falling to the ground. Tom doesn't say anything. She pull herself back up. She repeats the action... determinedly. swings her leg over again and sits squarely on the horse. remains still, but proud. As the day breaks, we leave them in silence -- Tom standi hands in pocket... Grace sitting up on the horse, proudly

Endless sky. Annie is jogging off in the distance when sh looks up and stops to see: Tom and Grace, both on horses, stopped on a rolling hill. They do not see her. Annie is filled with emotion... pride for her daughter,  gratitude for this amazing man. As the two ride off into the distance we do a slow:

Frank and Diane, with the Twins, dogs at their heels, rid front of the herd. Behind them, Joe riding alongside Grac Smokey and some Hands ride among the herd, keeping them m And riding behind the herd are Annie and Tom...

head_text.subj: VARIOUS MOMENTS THROUGHOUT THE DAY DURING THE

text: DRIVE... Highlighting, in particular, those in which the sexual tension between Tom and Annie is apparent.

The cattle stands in silhouette. We hear singing. Everyone is sitting around a campfire. Frank's playing th guitar, singing along with Tom. They laugh when a lyric o note goes wrong. Everyone is enjoying it. Annie, her arms around her knees, sits off by herself. Th song ends and people applaud. Frank hands the guitar to Hank;
Play that sweet one you know. The one  makes my wife here so friendly.
(slaps his shoulder)

You! Hank begins to play and sing a painfully pretty song. His sweet voice is stark contrast to his gruff, strongman  appearance. Frank offers his hand to Diane, she slaps it and laughs, he helps her up and they start to dance. As  everyone watches... Joe stands and offers his hand to Grace;
You wouldn't want to dance with me,  would you?
I don't thinks you'd want me tripping  all over you in front of everybody.
(sweetly)
I wouldn't let happen.
(affectionately)

You know, you're a good kid. Joe smiles and helps her up. They come together and start dancing. Annie is watching, holding her breath with gratitude. Tom notices Annie off by herself and crosses to her. He  extends his hand. She hesitates, looks again to Grace wit Joe, then accepts... His hand slide to her back. Her hand to his shoulder. The dance. Their bodies closer than they've ever been. Slowly she leans her head against his body. And surrenders, for moment... Diane sees them. She holds her husband fast, and buries h head on his neck.
MORE CATTLE DRIVE MANTAGE -- Taking Tom and Annie a bit  further in their intimacy; perhaps Tom takes extra specia care to explain things to Annie, or fix her saddle cinch, make her laugh...
The cows stands in the pasture, grazing. Annie and Diane cleaning some pots and pans in the stream.
Must be nice for you to take a few  days off from your work, huh?
Well, I have more than a few days, ha,  ha... I uh... I'm sort of... not an  editor anymore... right now... First  time I've said it out loud.
They fired you?
No, it's more like a leave of- (stops)
Ha, ha, ha. Yeah, they fired me.
You don't seem to upset?
Delayed shock. Or maybe not. I know  I could talk my way back if I wanted  or... go to another magazine,  someplace... Just not sure if I want  to.
Guess you don't have to figure it out  until you go home. This phrase "go home" stings Annie -- though Diane said i innocently.
Did you always know this was the life  you wanted?

I fell in love. After that, I never  thought about being anything but a  rancher's wife. I never saw it like I  was losing some other life, just felt  like I was gaining one. I know that's  not a popular opinion nowadays and I  ain't saying it's the right one. We  all have to find the life meant for us.
Frank's a good man.

They don't come better. But I don't  deny there are times I wonder about  things I won't have. Maybe one day I'll  get to see Egypt. Maybe not. But I know  if you try too many different lives,  you can wind up with no life at all...
Sounds like something Tom would say.
Yes, it does. Annie and Diane resume washing the dishes in silence. Ann deep in thought. Until Diane stops. After a beat, Annie  notices.
What?

Annie, I'm not good at this kind of talk  -- goes round and round a thing but  never comes to it -- so let's just say  what it is. When you first came here,  I didn't like you and I was worried. Tom  means a lot to me and this family. Don't  go looking here for whatever you looking  for. Don't make that man go through  something it took him a long time to see  his way clear out of the first time.
I don't think anybody can make Tom do  anything he didn't want.

He's a good man, Tom is. He's got a  gift, come from heaven above, I swear.  But he's still a man. And a woman can  lead a man into the middle of a mountain  lake -- and still make him think he's on  dry land. Diane's words ring in Annie's head.

Dead in stillness. The cattle dark and motionless. Everyo asleep in bedrolls around the pasture. Annie awakens, looks up at the moon, watching it go in an out of the clouds. She looks over to sleeping Grace... Th looks to where Tom is -- and sees his sleeping bag is emp Quietly, she rises and looks for him. She starts across the grass and sees him crossing on his  haunches, wearing a slicker, sitting in the grass by the  stream, drinking some water. She watches him. Tom senses something and turns. For a moment, they just l at each other -- half disbelieving the inevitable is so c at hand. Annie approaches as Tom rises. They meet. They kiss. Tentative at first, but more, just make that very, precious first moment of discovery last a long as it can. The kiss grows more passionate. They begi lose themselves in each other. Until, suddenly, aware of their surroundings, they part. words. Their expressions to each other tell all. Annie  separates herself and goes back to her bedroll... Tom sta in the grass, by the stream... the moving water, the nigh only sound.
The cattle drive returns. Tom, Annie, Grace, et al... are their horses, heading back towards the ranch when Grace s in the distance;

Dad? Annie looks up and sees: POV -- ROBERT has come to the ranch. He is waiting for th with his luggage beside a rental car... standing out like Like The Man In The Gray Flannel Suit in the middle of  Wyeth's "Christina's World."
Everyone is being introduced to Robert, as Grace hugs him from the side, never letting go of him. Frank, Diane -- w introduce their kids, then Tom and Robert shake hands...
This is Mr. Booker, Robert.
(extends hand)
Tom.
Hi. It's a pleasure. I'm very grateful  for the way you took in my girls here.  I bet you were surprised when they  just showed up out of nowhere.
Oh yeah... Laugh. Awkward silence...
Well I uh... I can already see a change. (hugging Grace)
And I'm very grateful to you. Robert is so sincere -- in that openly, modern, "express feelings" kind of way. Tom just nods.
Did you notice -- no cane?
I know. Amazing.
Can we show him Pilgrim, Tom?
Oh, we're gonna show your dad plenty.  Why don't you all get settled in and  we'll do the tour. Excuse me. As Tom walks away, a nervous Robert feels compelled to sa
See you later! Tom just nods and keeps walking. Annie and Robert face ea other for a beat.
Let's bring your bags inside.
Wait till you see this -- we have the  whole house to ourselves... The MacLean walk to the Creek House.

In the distance, we see the pick-up truck parked out in t pasture. Tom is standing with Robert -- in jeans, now -- Grace, telling Robert about the ranch. Robert has his arm around Grace, asking questions, interested in everything. Grace is loving being with her two favorite men...
Grace waits in the truck as Tom leads Robert through the and cowshit, climbs up and hops over a wood fence. Robert follows suit -- not as gracefully -- and gets a splinter.
Diane is busy in the kitchen when Annie enters.
Is there anything you need? I'm going  food-shopping.
Well, I am going to go after lunch.
No, no, I'll go -- just give me a  list. Annie is determined. She needs to be by herself for a bit

Tom continues his tour as the dogs run about them. Tom pa the dogs no attention, except to bark an order. Robert,  however, engages with them -- picking up a stick and thro it. A dog returns and gives it back. Robert kneels and be rubbing the dog's fur, talking to it, looking like an  anachronism in his baggy jeans with designer cowboy belt spanking new designer cowboy boots. Tom waits patiently for Robert, who... and carries on wit the dog a bit too long. When Robert gets up, he habituall brushes the dirt off his jeans, maybe even his boots, and makes sure his outfit is hanging properly.
Grace is in the stall with Pilgrim. Once again, close eno to touch him, which he allows. Outside the stall, stand Robert and Tom. Robert squeezes splinter...
I can't believe it's the same horse.
We still have a way to go.
How much longer do you think? Tom understands this man wants his family back.
Well, like I told your wife, it's  really up to Pilgrim.
I understand...
Everyone is seated around the table, eating, talking, lau Grace is right by her father's side. Frank's in the middl telling Robert:

We thought we lost him in the snow  storm... Told the kids. Had a funeral  for the damn thing. Finally, snow  stops. Staring to warm up. I go out  and start cleaning the truck...  Goddamn if that dog doesn't jump out  from the back seat covered in snow...  I nearly stained myself.
He thought it was a ghost.
A dog ghost! Laughter all around.

Everyone is outside enjoying the night after a long day. Diane and Annie are on the porch. Diane is showing Annie she does her needlepoint. Annie is genuinely interested. Tom and Frank and Robert are sitting out front. Grace is Robert's feet. Joe sits on the ground in front of his fat opposite Grace.
Is the poverty worse, now, you  think?
I haven't been back in over twenty  years, but I wouldn't be surprised.  The population's larger.
What were you doing over in India?
Uh, this was right after college. I  was in the Peace Corps.
That right? Back on Diane and Annie, who hear the laughter O.S. and l Diane smiles, seeing how much Grace is enjoying her dad.
